Colony A Strategy Game is a strategic conflict and colony building game. Small counters represent warships and townships, which are deployed on the main map. Status sheets record the condition of the ships and status of the construction of the colony.
Colony building along with conflict takes place on the same turn, so decisions need to be made to balance advancing victory conditions versus elimination of opponent's assets.
The winner is the first to build an entire colony, which consists of nine CM's being built.

21252.name: Monkey Business
21252.description:
(Note: Text taken from back of box.)

For 4 or more players. Ages 10 and up.

As the Zoo Keeper (or Host) you will be responsible for providing a play area (or cage) for your invited guests. MONKEY BUSINESS will make your next party a wild one no matter how tame your guests are. Give each guest a card when they arrive and let the party begin. Each player must follow the instructions on their card, which will set off a chain of bizarre events. All players try to determine other players' particular peculiarities and what causes them to occur. It's a hilarious game of cause and effect for party animals of all ages! There's no escaping the fun!

21253.name: Ascent
21253.description:
Ascent is a game about getting to the top! It is a game of mountain climbing. Through the play of cards you try an attempt to climb the mountain choosing a route which best suits the resources you have available to you. You may choose one of five routes to climb. Each has its only difficulties and requirements.

Through the use of card play you gradually climb the mountain choosing the best route available to you, surrendering cards as you climb. There is always the possibility of disaster as dictated by possible avalanches which can force you to start all over again from the base camp. The avalanche possibility is dictated by a nice system of die rolls. Roll 2D6, first is the route that is effected from 1 to 5, the second is the increase in avalanche likelihood. Each route has an avalanche dial on the board as the points amass on this dial the likelihood of an avalanche gets nearer. If the dial clicks around to the 12 position an avalanche occurs and it will knock climbers back to base camp who are caught on that route.

Interesting game of tension and resource management with a fair amount of luck thrown in. Nice looking board and cool mountain climbers. Some strategic play possibilities.

Components:

8 climbers
Equipment cards
Weather Protection cards
2d6

21254.name: Antonine! The Battle for Caledonia
21254.description:
Antonine! The Battle for Caledonia is a game where the Picts and the Romans go Head to Head fighting to either gain control 4 of the Antonine Wall Forts or to capture 4 of the opponents pieces.

The game is played on a 13 by 13 board which represents the area around the Antonine Wall between the Fort at New Kilpatrick and the Fort at Kinneil.

The game play is via die roll. Players roll 1d6 and 1d4. The result is the number of squares you may move in two different directions but not diagonally. If you land exactly on an opponents piece it is captured and is taken to one of your own camps where it stays unless released by an opponents counter landing on the camp it is trapped in.

You can capture a fort in the same manner. If it is occupied by an opponents piece that too would be captured.

A fun little game which can be challenging and frustrating as you must use your exact die rolls and you must move! Can get tricky in the latter stages of the game! A good move and capture game.

Components:

Board
6 Roman Soldiers
6 Pict Warriors
1 D4
1 D6
Rules

21255.name: Le Balene
21255.description: "The Whales" - Italian game issued for Greenpeace campaign against whales hunting. 108 double faced cards for a fun party game where players creates absurd but formally correct phrases to close their hand.

21257.name: Eat It!
21257.description: Here’s a trivia game you can really sink your teeth into! Test your taste buds with fun trivia questions about the foods you love to eat, from Chocolate & Candy to Snacks & Desserts. What kind of animal is Cheetos’ mascot, Chester? How many fudge stripes are there on a Keebler Fudge Stripes Cookie – 3, 5, 6, or 7? When Americans scream for ice cream, what is their favorite topping? The answers – A Cheetah, 5, and Chocolate Syrup! This fun and tasty trivia game redefines the food pyramid, with “Snack Attack”, “Cookies”, “Ice Cream & Desserts”, “Candy” and “Chocolate” categories occupying the spaces. Answer the questions correctly, make your way to the top of the Snacks & Sweets Pyramid, and you’ll be the Snacks & Sweets Trivia Superstar! Game comes with Eat It! Game Board, 1 Box of 400 Eat It! Question & Answer Cards, 1 Set of 35 Eat It! Pyramid Cards, 1 Die, 6 Game Pieces, and Game Instructions. For 2 – 6 Players, Ages 13 and Up.

21258.name: Concatenate!
21258.description:
Concatenate, Reel Geeks™ edition is the exciting, linking movie trivia game that puts player's movie knowledge to the test! Of course you don't need to be a movie critic to play, but if you are we've got you covered!

With thousands of questions, multiple skill levels, and a unique game play you'll be hooked the first time you play!

Be the first player to answer questions correctly along the filmstrip, link your way to the End Game and Concatenate to win!

21259.name: Sports Dice: Baseball
21259.description: Travel Baseball game - 5 defensive dice (defensive men), 2 red offensive dice, 3 pawns as runners.

21260.name: The Great Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade Game
21260.description:
Illustrator Gerry Olin Greengrass loved a parade so much she decided to create a board game to hold onto the feeling year-round. Game enthusiasts now get to join in the fun with the release of The Great Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade Game. As in the annual Macy's march down Broadway, Santa Claus takes center stage. The player (two to four can compete) whose Santa travels the entire parade route and enters the Herald Square store first wins. Depending on the roll of the dice — and the float or balloon square landed on — game pieces move forward or loss ground. "Surprise cards" keep the action going.

Greengrass enjoys playing the game with her 4-year-old grandson, but says she'll be out on the real parade route again this holiday.

21261.name: The Amazing Chan and the Chan Clan Game
21261.description:
1973 Hanna-Barbera Productions, Inc.

OBJECT:
To be the first player to bring Charlie the missing clue that correctly matches the clue space on which Charlie is standing.

21263.name: Can-Doo
21263.description:
PREPARATION:
Stack the cans in a pyramid. Shuffle all cards and place the deck face down, in easy reach of all players.

THE PLAY:
A player is chosen to be first. He takes a card from the card deck and now attempts to remove the matching can from the stack. He keeps the can and the card and the next player goes.

FALLING CANS:
If on a player's turn only one can drops from the stack, his turn is over and he must return the fallen can to the stack and the card to the bottom of the card deck. He scores no points for that round. If more than one can drops from the stack, the game is over and the player who upsets the stack scores no points for that round.

WINNING THE GAME:
Each player counts the total point score of his cards. Highest point score wins the game.

21264.description:
An ancient chess variant which uses a 16 X 4 circular board. Piece movement is the same except that Queen moves only one space diagonally and Bishop moves two diagonally, jumping the first space. Additionally, two pawns blocking one another's paths may be removed (both are removed).

A modern variant by David Reynolds using the same board is known as Circular Chess.
21264.name: Byzantine Chess

21265.description: A popular chess variant with a 12 X 8 board. Pieces are arrayed in four columns. New pieces are added including a Counselor and Spy. Couriers and Bishops are similar but move slightly differently. The Queen starts in an open position in front of most pawns.
21265.name: Courier Chess

21266.name: Patron-ow
21266.description: Players take turns playing 'Russian Roulette'. Beginning of the players turn one out of 7 bullets is 'loaded'. Player rolls a die and can take any number of bullets (one after the other...) until he stops or draws the loaded one. He receives points equal to the number of bullets times the die roll - of course these are negative when he drew the loaded one.

21267.name: Tryline
21267.description:
"Tryline" is a head to head Rugby Union simulation.
It consists of Fast Action Cards, Team Cards, a color coded pitch made up of squares and a blue and red reversible counter that changes color once possession changes.

The FAC's control the Kicking, Passing, Running, Rucks, Mauls, Scrums and Lineouts etc. These are turned over by players depending on the previous FAC command or on the strategic placing of a Team Card.
The Team Cards have 2 functions only one of which can be used when it is played. The first function called the Territory Part uses a move value attached to Kicking, Passing and Running etc. which are implemented when the player has been allowed to on the FAC. The second function is the Action part which can be used to counter play determined by FAC's or indeed by the placing of other Team Cards.

Tries are awarded when the counter lands on the Tryline by means of Running, Passing and Tap Penalties. If Kicks, Mauls and Scrums move the counter onto the Tryline then players turn a FAC to see what the outcome is on the Grounded Ball section.

At an advanced level, once players become used to the basic game, Tryline offers you the opportunity to introduce Substitution Cards and a Yellow Card system.

21268.name: Mesopotamia
21268.description:
"Crawl into the skin of a Mesoptamian ruler during the age of the great Hammurabi of Babylon. Relive how kings managed to secure their power and gain the respect of their tribes. The construction of temples and canals, agricultural development and military victories can all spread your fame and secure your rule. Make constant decisions on how best to govern your land: rely on the rule of law and the gentle persuading powers of the Ishtar priestesses and strife for a blossoming agricultural system, or turn to the fanaticism of the Marduk priests and the battle strength of their troops. However you choose to exert your rule - you can only win the game if your rule is so successful that your fame, in the eyes of your subjects, has acquired a god-like status, making you the undisputed ruler of Mesopotamia."

This is the first game from Hilmar Möhlmann and has undergone several years of development. Its final version was made available to the gaming community through his website and ebay. Having acquired a copy it is obvious that this is a labor of love. The design of board and cards is beautiful - the rules are well tested, clearly presented and relatively short for such a ambitious game. Ongoing support for players is in place through website updates and direct communication. And having just acquired my copy, I wonder if the price asked actually covers the materials provided. An impressive entry for this budding designer and a one to seek out for players who enjoy games like "Settlers of Catan" but yearn for something a bit meatier and with a stronger theme. With an Arthurian themed game in the pipeline, this one-man act might be an interesting one to follow.

The aim of the game is to have the most military units and construction works of your color on the board. This can be done over 2 to 5 rounds. Resources can be acquired through natural growth, trade and military conquests. Trade takes place along caravan routes. Players can trade freely with their trading partner, pay toll to players whose territory is crossed en-route, or exchange resources against a set course with the bank. These resources can then be used to generate new buildings or units. Each turn a player can use an influence card, adding flavor and variety without unbalancing strategic play. A nice twist is that players who allow toll-free trading between other players if the caravan route passes their territory see a generous windfall from the opening of this trade route in the next round, when some resources are added to the storage in that province. Each year round ends with construction and military campaigns. Conflicts are settled by dice rolls which are modified by markers on the board.

This game appeared in 2 versions:

The self-published "2D" version (quality is at the very high end of desktop publishing).
Some assembly is required, mainly joining the 8 pages that from the superbly produced full colour game board. In total you get 39 multicolour A4 sheets, including several photo-quality prints, six pages of clear and well presented rules, and lots of event cards, markers and game aids.

The wooden case with the handmade "3D" version of the game board is fit for a king, and for those with a rather large game budget.

21269.name: Finger Football
21269.description:
From the Publisher:

Zelosport Finger Football was created around the age-old concept of flicking a folded piece of paper across a tabletop until any portion of the triangle-shaped football hangs over the table's edge for a touchdown. Six points is awarded for the touchdown and the player then kicks an extra point through his opponent's "finger goal posts."

Zelosport's version has a high gloss, durable, multi-colored playing surface designed very much like a real football field. It's actual size is 2'x4' and fits easily on most kitchen or dining room tables. The back side of the playing surface is covered in a non-slip material allowing the game to be played on most surfaces without constant movement.

The paper football has been replaced by two very different objects. A one inch plastic "slider" with a small ball bearing inside is flicked down the playing surface for runs, passes, touchdowns and 2 point conversions. For kicking field goals, a three inch foam football is included. Also included with the game are two dice used by the defense to determine the play required by the offensive player, 8 rubber washers and a ball marker to mark the line of scrimmage and the score, down and plays completed, as well as a set of rules.

21270.name: Fortress Chess
21270.description: An ancient four player chess variant from Russia. The board contains four 4 X 4 blocks out the outer corners of a 12 X 12 board. These spaces make for good defense in a four player chess assault.

21271.name: Commando Chess
21271.description:
A chess variant using pieces based off of modern military units. There are seven types of pieces: infantry, calvary tanks, armor tanks, fighter planes, attack helicopters, bomber squadrons and a HQ Flag acting as the king.
The pieces have different movements from the standard chess game. The number of pieces is the same, 16 on each side, and the board is a standard 8x8. However, in living up to its name the game board has a camouflage background.
The ground units move and capture similar to chess pieces, but the three air unit types may jump over other pieces like the knights in chess. The bomber is a partial exception to this rule, it can only jump over pieces on its own side.

21275.name: Outburst: Travel Edition
21275.description:
Now experience Outburst! fun anywhere you go! Outburst Travel Edition offers all the original uproarious game play in a handy take-along design.

Just as in the original Outburst! games, teams have 60 seconds to yell out answers that fit familiar categories. Teams may shout out as many answers as possible, but only the 10 answers that appear on the Topic Card will score points.

This pocket-size versions includes a 60-second Timer, Viewer/Card Holder containing 160 Common-Knowledge Topics, Scoreboard and Market.

Outburst Travel Edition is as easy as it is fun. Try it - Can you name "10 Annoying Things That Other Drivers Do?" You have one minute, go!

21276.description:
A board game of magical invention ...

Imagine a world where myth is real -- where wizards wield magic beyond the ken of other mortals. Imagine yourself as one of these mages, dwelling in a mystical bastion with your allies and servants, unlocking secret powers and creating wonders. Every thirty-three years the Grand Tribunal is held, attracting other wizards from far and wide to show off their magical creations for the inspection and approval of the archmages. These powerful judges vote on the best, and invite the winner to join their ranks as a new archmage -- a true master of the art of magic!

Grand Tribunal is a board game for three to five players, inspired by the Ars Magica roleplaying game. In Grand Tribunal, players use Vis tokens to activate cards representing magic item types, spell categories, and resources, which they then assemble into powerful magic items. Each round, players place their votes for the item types and spell categories they're most likely to be able to play. Three times during the game -- at the periodic Tribunals -- players are presented with 1st-, 2nd-, and 3rd-place awards for creating magic items with item types and spell categories that match those with the most votes. The player at the end of the game with the most points based on those awards wins!
21276.name: Grand Tribunal

boardgamefamily.7757: From RPG books to board games

21277.name: Nobody is Perfect 2
21277.description: Improved version of 'Nobody is Perfect'. Now you can play with a maximum of 10 people. The picture questions have been replaced by Yes/No questions.

21278.name: SuDoKu Mania
21278.description:
Sudoku is played on a grid divided into 9 large squares (3x3), with each square made up of 9 cells (3x) for a total of 81 cells.

The objects of Sudoku is to fill in a (9x9) grid in such way that every row, column and (3x3) square contain each number from 1 to 9 once, and only once.

In this game, the rules book show about 150 grids and their solutions.

45 Easy grids
45 Intermediate grids
45 Difficult grids
15 Evil grids

Like you'll see in the game material, you game play with the tiles or by writing directly on the board.

Game material :

1 dry-erase game board
90 number tiles
1 black dry-erase marker
1 red dry-erase marker
1 game rules and grids booklet

This game can be played alone or in group.

21279.name: Convoy
21279.description:
Players take it in turns to run convoys of ships in partnerships. Two players are chosen by spinning the compass card to create a convoy. They become players 'North' and 'South'. All other players act individually to try and stop them.

A convoy is a running sequence of 4 'Merchantmen' cards and the 'Home' card. The merchantmen are numbered from 1-6 so there are 3 ways of making a convoy. The convoy has to be in North's hands to score, so North and South work together to realign their cards. When they have a convoy North calls 'Convoy' and the round ends.

Any other player (not North) can halt a round by declaring their hand when they have collected certain configurations. Other cards
include 'torpedoes', 'mines', 'cruisers', 'destroyers' and 'submarines'.

After adding up the points the winner is the first to 1000 points.

21280.name: Black Quest
21280.description: Black Quest is a game designed to educate the player in the history of African-Americans. The game consists of a deck of question cards, a deck of bonus cards, a die, a tumbler, and a score pad. A turn consists of a players rolling the die, then answering the question from a question card corresponding to the number on the die. A roll of 6 allows the player to answer a question from the Bonus deck. The turn continues until a question is answered incorrectly. Each correct answer is awarded 5 points, while bonus questions are worth 10 points. The first player to reach 250 points wins.

21281.name: Locarno: Europe 1926
21281.description:
Locarno - Europe 1926 seeks to portray the restored "Concert of European Powers" following the Treaty of Locarno, Oct. 1925. Players assume the role of European statesmen seeking to outclass their geopolitical rivals and attain a position of predominance.

The game is based upon Allan B. Calhamer's classic Diplomacy. However, its treatment of minor powers is strikingly different as these have their own military units. Players secretly bid influence points in order to obtain the support of these lesser powers.

Re-implemented by:

The Road to War: Europe 1936

21283.name: Il Ribaltone
21283.description:
"Il Ribaltone" is a game on Italian politics. It focuses players' attention to the intrigues and machinations that made the Italian governments so weak during the First Republic.
Each player takes the role of a political party. His goal is to achieve the most political influence by cumulating the head chief offices inside the Government during the 5 years covered by the game.
Laws "ad personam", scandals, bankruptcies, breakdowns of institutions, strange affairs, volatile alliances, backstabbing, riots inside the Parliaments... everything can happen during a match.

The game can be FREELY downloaded for print, cut & play at:

www.calvinuslab.tk

Italian version is the only one currently available. The game subject is strictly linked to Italian politics, so no English version will be published.

21284.name: Alcatraz Escape
21284.description: A dice game for 2 players. You have to transport your prisoners from one side to the other. The first one with all his prisoners at the other side is the winner. You have to throw with a black and a white dice. The numbers on the stones represent the escape gate. For instance when you throw 3 with the white stone you put one of your prisoners in the third white gate, with the black stone in the black gate. With six you may choose which gate.

21285.name: Giants and Castles
21285.description: Players move their Giants around the board, ripping castles apart looking for treasure rooms. First player to acquire 4 treasure rooms (as the giants are trying to build their own golden castles) wins the game. Each player gets 5 actions points a turn. Action points can be spent to move to an adjacent space, pick up an adjacent room from the top of a castle or giant’s stack, place the top room of your stack on an adjacent square, or cast a spell, provided you have enough rooms to give to the local sorceresses.

boardgamehonor.20042: 2007 Games Magazine Best New Word Game Winner

21286.name: Parlay
21286.description:
Parlay is a card game that challenges players to make the best poker hand and the best word that they can from their cards.

Parlay uses an artistically enhanced 52 card deck of familiar playing cards, with the addition of a letter and point value on each card. Players decide which cards to hold and which to exchange in an attempt to improve their word, their poker hand, and hopefully both.

Like traditional poker, players can enjoy a variety of games like the favorites 'Texas Hold'em' and 'Five Card Draw', or original games like 'Unlucky 7's' and 'Wild I's'.

Unlike traditional poker, Parlay involves no betting or wagering. However, players are faced with an element of poker-style risk, where every hand they must decide whether to 'FOLD' for guaranteed points, or risk their points and 'STAY' in an attempt to win out over opponents for big point bonuses.

Parlay also introduces 'Wordbluffing', where players are invited to play oddly spelled words to trick their opponents into calling their bluff to knock them out of the hand. Players can also try to get away with fake or misspelled words, hoping their bluff won't be called. Wordbluffing usually results in lots of laughs.

Parlay comes with a deck of 52 casino quality playing cards, 2 jokers, 1 info card, 6 stay/fold game chips, 80 sheet score pad, and an instruction booklet. Players 2-6, Ages 9 and up.

21287.description: In Bison every player is representing a native American Indian tribe. Aim is to settle in an area rich of bison, fish and turkeys. The tribe need bison as food and clothes (leather), they need fish for food and the turkeys and their feathers for rituals and adornment. The players catch bison, fish and turkeys and keep the score as markers on their own overview board. The animal markers are used to survive, to explore new land and to buy canoes and tents at the market. The player who has the most animals wins the game.
21287.name: Bison: Thunder on the Prairie

21289.name: Birds Eye Race Against Time
21289.description:
"An exciting race against time to get your peas to the Birds Eye factory. But watch out, your opponents' harvesters and shuttle lorries aren't far behind. And your peas may not be small enough or picked quickly enough to satisfy Birds Eye quality controllers. So get your harvesters rolling. The first grower to unload a batch of peas wins!"

A collect a coupon promotional game which Birds Eye offered in 1981 to its consumers suitable for Ages 7 and up.

The game is split into 2 phases, Harvesting and Delivery.

Each player takes it in turns to roll the dice and move around the outside spiral of the board representing "The farm" and stop at various harvest areas to collect magnetic pea counters which stick to the top of your harvester.
Action Cards are drawn whenever a player lands on an action card space, consequences range between delays or move backs and extra moves or turns.

The player then aims to get to the transfer area and begin the delivery phase taking the shortest route they can to reach the factory. Delays or detours are printed on the board and must be taken if landed on.

At the factory the player draws cards in order to unload peas of the matching color.

The standout feature of the game are the two sets of playing pieces (Harvesters and Lorries) which were nicely detailed with the Birds Eye logo on the side and had a small piece of metal in the top for the magnetic peas to stick to.

21290.description:
Map Pax 1 is an Advanced Squad Leader compatible expansion concerning the actions of the US 27th Infantry at Item Pocket, Okinawa, in 1944. This folio-style package includes an original 22"x32" color map, 10 new scenarios and a unique Cave Set Up play aid.

Expands:

Advanced Squad Leader
21290.name: Blood & Iron Map Pax 1

21291.description: Folio-style accessory for use with Advanced Squad Leader, depicting the allied efforts to capture Point 593 near the Monte Cassino monastery, held at that time time by elements of the German 1st Parachute Division. Players may recreate the many and varied attacks by Indian, American, New Zealand, Polish and Free French troops as they attempted to dislodge the stubborn and resourceful Fallschirmjaegers. Includes 8 new scenarios and 4 new campaign games and a 22"x32" map to play them on.
21291.name: Carnage at Cassino

21292.description: An Advanced Squad Leader compatible scenario and map pack depicting the actions around the area in Normandy that would later become known as "The Marcus Heim Causeway". Contains 12 small-action scenarios and a large-hex 25"x35" color map.
21292.name: Airborne Stand!

boardgamehonor.19188: 2006 Japan Boardgame Prize Best Foreign Game for Beginners Nominee

21293.description:
In 11th century Ireland players try to gather amulets with the help of five druids. Each amulet is divided in 9 parts and the player with the most complete amulets wins the game.

Other Celtic games.
21293.name: Celtica

21294.name: NoNo
21294.description:
From the publisher:

NoNo is a fast and exciting game for the whole family (it is also very suitable as a party game). The aim is to find a certain term most quickly. The terms which have to be found are determined by cards and special dice.
If you make a mistake, you get negative points.

- always different because of the special dice
- inexpensive
- a very good game for a party or while traveling
- very quick to explain
- the players learn something about their language

Contents: 75 playing cards, 4 special dice, 1 rules booklet

21295.name: Viva Zapata!
21295.description:
Viva Zapata! is a traditional hex-and-counters wargame, which pits Mexican rebels against the Mexican government. Gameplay is pretty standard (for a wargame), including terrain modifiers for movement and combat, as well as a pretty standard combat resolution table.

Apart from the theme, the originality of the game comes from the use of trains (necessary for both players, as their forces are scattered throughout the map at the beginning of the game), and dynamite to blow up the railroad tracks.

21296.name: Daisho
21296.description: A free downloadable card game from Warp Spawn games. The subject is man-to-man combat between Japanese characters. The game can be found at http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/Daisho.html. A set of the cards needed can be found at http://digilander.libero.it/zak965/thoth/daisho.zip.

21297.name: Between the Posts
21297.description:
A rugby simulation that tries to capture the end to end excitement of top class Rugby Union. Using real team and player stats, the game aims to simulate a full match rather than just the attacking highlights system used in it's predecessor, "Line Out".

Many team cards are available, where real teams are rated for Attack and Defence plus their ability in set scrums, rucks, loose mauls and line outs, as well as individually rated players for each team - to produce statistically accurate results and scorers.

Players roll dice and refer to various charts depending on the action, field position, and team ratings, to determine the outcome of events. Players have opportunities to dictate teams tactics or actions during the match, and the result is the full end-to-end flow of a match, the grim battle between the opposing packs, tactical defensive play, the power of the loose maul, the rucks and scrums driving forward, and the sweeping open play as the backs come into the game.

It's the Strat-O-Matic of rugby gaming!

21298.name: Line Out
21298.description:
"Line Out" is a replay simulation of Rugby Union.

Teams are rated for Attack and Defence plus their ability in set scrums, rucks, loose mauls and line outs.

The game recreates the 'highlights' [potentially dangerous attacks] of a match based on the attach / defence ratings of the teams.

When either team's Attack number is rolled a simple procedure establishes how the attack started, which player has possession and where exactly on the field of play the attack is centered as you join the action. From then on dice rolls on one or other of the various Charts plot the outcome of the attack until it either breaks down or points are scored. Most of the actions are taken from the Action Chart which is common to both teams, but approximately one in six are taken from the Team's own Team Card, helping recreate that team's particular style of play, strengths and weaknesses. Other 'actions' are dependent on individual Player Ratings.

A marker is moved on the Field of Play to chart the development of the attack, another marker on the Team Card shows who has possession, and a third is used on the Time Clock to keep track of time.

Team Cards use named players and substitutes, with individual Player Ratings to produce accurate results and scorers. Teams from many seasons and competitions available, allowing for some great "what if" matchups, as well as full season replays.

21299.description:
A head to head rugby game, where players play cards to move the ball around the pitch or to attempt to stop their opponents moves.

Various situations are catered for by the cards held, from rucks and rolling mauls, to sweeping moves by the backs. Several kicking options are also available from little grubber kicks, to towering bombs, to huge touch finding clearance kicks - although beware of your opponent scooping up the loose ball and cutting through your defense.

This is a fast paced, end to end, rugby game, which is quick to learn, and no two matches ever play the same.

Additional rules are also included for playing with 3 or 4 players, or even solo.
21299.name: The Great Running Game

21300.name: In-Sekt-Surprise
21300.description:
Game from the same series as e.g. Patron-Ow and Ham-N-Ex etc.

Start of each round a small bottle of champagne (without champagne of course...) and a bug each are hidden beneath one out of four miniature champagne coolers. Player chooses one cooler and turns it over - if it's the champagne or nothing he scores some points and may continue if he wants. If he finds the bug he gets negative points.

21301.name: Warlock
21301.description:
This small game was inspired by the Warlock stories by Larry Niven. Players use mana to create creatures and cast spells. Each player starts with equal powers.

A game comes with a rule book with a combat table, a 8 1/2 x 12 inch hex grid, a sheet of spells, a 5 x 6 inch sheet of 90 counters representing warlocks, conjured beings, and effects of spells.

The creatures include bats, goblins, wolves, eagles, cobras, flying dragons, fire-breathing dragons, and demons.

21302.name: Hearts Playing Board Game

3136.name: Tee Pee Toys, Jessup Paper Box Co.

21302.description:
The version has two different games.

The first game involves players moving playing pieces from start to finish. Players attempt to take tricks of balloons, stars, and flowers while avoiding the hearts. The player taking the highest numbered card in the leading suit takes the trick. After all cards are played, players move their markers ahead 1 space for each non-heart and back 1 space for each heart.

The second game determines movement by using cards and a spinner.

21303.name: Mental Blocks "The Block Party"
21303.description:
This game is published by Perigee Books, a member of The Putnam Publishing Group, in The United States and by General Publishing Company in Canada under the exclusive license from The Stonesong Press, Inc. "The Block Party" is a trademark of The Putnam Publishing Group.

This game is made up of 16 cubes that allow players to find up to 96 pictures and almost 2000 pictorial variations by arranging the cubes into four-by-four squares or other patterns.

The game has three levels of difficulty, or you can create your own game.

"Block Party" is the first version to be published in a material other than wood.

21304.name: Billion Dollar Player
21304.description:
From the publisher:

The top sports stars receive many income opportunities. Players sign deals, receive awards, and lead their sports in categories that help and hurt their earning potential. Poor performance in their sport reduces the next contract offer sheet. The wrong endorsement deal can ruin an image and cause a player to miss out on millions of dollars. Now, the average fan has the opportunity to make money like the best athletes around today. Play Billion Dollar Player to win!


From the games website, doesn't look like this game is in print anymore. (March 2007)

21305.name: Spanish Chess
21305.description: Similar to modern European chess except that the board is 10 X 8 and features a new piece called the Archer which moves forward like a Rook but moves backwards like a bishop.

21307.description:
Billed as a "party" game, players are dealt various teams competing in a fictitious 32 team straight knockout rugby tournament.
A die is rolled to determine in which of 6 countries the event will be held - which will benefit certain teams during the tournament.

Teams are rated as A, B, or C - and matchups are resolved by rolling one of five specially numbered dice per team, depending on the strength of the them and the opposition. Winning a match gains the teams 'manager' a chip, which can be traded in for a 'penalty' token at certain times. Playing a penalty token will add 3 points to your teams score in a match - allowing for a small amount of strategy.

Once all the matches in a round are resolved, the remaining teams are reshuffled, and the next round played until the overall winner is determined - although rules are included for "buying" teams if all your own teams are knocked out.
21307.name: World Cup Rugby

21308.name: Corporate Circles
21308.description:
(Description taken from the back of the box)

A highly competitive fast paced adult game (playing time approximately 1 hour) where players move in and out of three CORPORATE CIRCLES trying to become the first person to make $1,000,000.00 cash. This is done by building up one's corporate holdings through the purchase of companies or by acquiring your opponent's companies in hostile takeovers or corporate raids.

This is a game where trivia knowledge can't help you; monopolies can be broken and there is always a risk of your opponents conspiring against you. Your common sense is your only ally.

It's a no holds barred [sic] game where alliances are loosely formed and broken as fast as companies hit the auction block.

21309.description:
From the Publishers site:

Armored Assault
ICE presents Space Master: Armored
Assault, an intricate boardgame of gripping, tactical planet side combat in the far future. Armored Assault also doubles as the vehicular expansion set for Space Master: The Role Playing Game'.

THE ULTIMATE IN FLEXIBILITY
Now you can simulate decisive futuristic planet-bound battles! Command small unit actions with a handful of tracked AFVs, or mobilize full-blown campaigns, mustering subs, surface ships, walkers, gray tanks, artillery, aircraft, and more!
Choose Basic, Standard or Advanced Rules to define your game's level of detail and realism. Challenge yourself further by adding even more exacting Optional Rules.
Armored Assault is completely compatible with Space Master: The Role Playing Game and Star Strike. It includes comprehensive construction systems for tracked vehicles, infantry teams, powered armor troopers, rear echelon assets, and more.

Space Master: Armored Assault includes:
Assault Book
• The Basic Game: Simple, easy-to-learn rules and scenarios for beginners.
• The Standard Game: Comprehensive rules for a wide range of surface combat units, weapon types, scenarios, and campaign suggestions.
• The Advanced Game: Rules which incorporate aerial and submersible vehicles into the action.
• Optional Rules: Add-on game systems for master players who desire even more detail.
• Construction Rules: Custom-design guidelines for infantry teams, powered troopers, ordnance, aircraft, rear echelon assets, installations, robots, and all manner of vehicles.
Tables and Forms Book
• Combat Tables: Attack charts for auto, MLA, and lob cannons, laser, blaster, disrupter, ion and plasma cannons, as well as shaped charge, seeking explosive, proximity explosive, nuclear and matter/ antimatter warheads. Also, there are 9 critical result tables for attacks against soft and hard targets, and another 5 for personal casualties.
• Game Charts: The most commonly used charts in one section for quick reference.
Playing Pieces
• 130 Vehicle Counters: Full color counters depicting a variety of vehicle types.
• 480 Utility Markers: Troops, torpedoes, mines, terrain, and other game system markers.
• 4 Tactical Maps: Each displays unique terrain features on a 100 meter hex scale. -
• 2 Percentile Dice

Offsite note:
Although this game is designed to be used with the space master RPG is a fully functional and fun stand- alone wargame.
21309.name: Armored Assault

21310.name: Tenpin To Go
21310.description: Tenpin To Go is a tabletop bowling game, which includes ten plastic pins and a metal ball as well as a cardboard lane. Players take turns setting up and knocking down pins and scoring their frames.

21311.name: Try-Max
21311.description:
A strategy game which is a cross between rugby and draughts.
Players have 15 counters representing their team, and alternate moving one of their counters each turn. There is no concept however of a ball, so any piece making it to the opponents end of the pitch is deemed to have scored.

Different pieces have slightly different rules, so the fullback may move sideways (to block an opponent), while a winger may move double on certain turns. There are also spaces which bring into play referee and kicking cards to add additional options.

21312.description: From the publisher: "ClanTroops is a supplement to the BattleTech: Battletroops game, providing 16 scenarios set during the Clan invasion. ClanTroops features rules expansions dealing with new terrain, weapons, equipment, an both Inner Sphere and Elemental battle armor. ClanTroops also contains five new mapsheets and a variety of counters, including stand-up counters for both types of battle armor."
21312.name: BattleTech: ClanTroops

21313.name: Mad Manic Move
21313.description:
Mad Manic Move is a family game of moving home.
Players must travel around the board, visiting places as indicated by their 'on the move' card, chosen at the start of the game.
With a variety of cards and pitfalls throughout the game, mad manic move is a fast paced, fun game taking a dig at difficulties of moving home.
The objective of the game is to collect all 9 house cards, answering trivia questions all the way, before moving into you new home.

21314.name: Antburger Hill
21314.description:
“The spiders are on the march, they have their sights set on Antburger Hill, Grid Ref. 86N 27.4E.
The bugle sounds and Ants scurry to man hurried fortifications. With stout hearts the defenders stand in wait for the spiders to rush their hill.”

The ants must defend their anthill against the rush of the spider hordes.

“Hold that hill at all costs.”

Using cunning and tactics, deploy your troops carefully against the rampant spider horde.
Win or lose the ants must defend their homes against the spider attack.
Its up to you to stop the spider advance before they destroy the whole ant colony.

21315.name: letterHEAD
21315.description: A unscramble the letters game, letterHEAD includes over 300 cards with mixed-up letters on the backs of each. During game play, a card is turned over and the letters are revealed. For example, all players will see a card with these letters, "RUNTYCE". The first player has 30-seconds to attempt to unscramble the letters to make a word. If he/she is unsuccessful, then it is up for grabs. If successful, then he/she would have spouted out, "century". The player would move ahead and maintain turn. letterHEAD's cards are, for the most part, very challenging. If you a really good at this game, then you can get the Genius cards, available through Enterfection Games.

21316.name: Fish'n Derby
21316.description: Compete at the Fish'n Derby on this lake on a board. Travel around the lake to find the best fish'n spot and go fishing. If you're in the right spot, you automatically catch a fish. If you're not in the best fish'n spot, then you must roll high enough to catch a fish. The fish you catch will range in weight from 1 to 10 lbs at various lengths. Each round only lasts so long as you must decide what fish to keep or throw away. At the end of each round, compete for one of the three trophies. Win all three and win the game.

21317.name: Deception
21317.description: A cartoon-like stock market game for players Ages 12 and up, Deception requires basic buy/sell principles. Each player will buy and sell shares of stocks, hoping to make enough money to buy the luxuries required to win the game. Included are secret cards (can raise havoc from your competitors) business cards (for last minute trades), and market cards (large cards that show the current prices for each stock). The longer you hold on to a specific stock, the more money you can make on dividends. However, the longer you have a stock, the more likely it will go bankrupt before you can sell it. Deception is a fairly ruthless business game, but it provides for lots of laughs.

21318.name: Hog Auction
21318.description: Each player owns a farm. The goal of each player is to expand their farms after making money at the hog auction. To do this, farmers must buy pigs one round and sell them when they get back to the auction. On the way back to the auction the market could fall and a farmer could lose money or a natural disaster could hit a player's farm an he could lose a barn. There are all kinds of questions that each farmer must ask him/herself during game play. How much should I bid on pigs? Should I buy insurance risk it? Can I afford to expand my farm right now?

21319.name: Grow2Learn
21319.description:
From the publisher's website:
GROW2LEARN is an educational series of six card games that use the same board. Focused on memory retention and cognitive learning development, the six activities progress for various levels of comprehension. This game was developed for children in pre-K to grade two.
1) Build early memory and picture-matching skills.
2) Develop phonics skills in beginning sounds.
3) Enhance shape, color, and visual-perceptual skills.
4) Learn addition with number exercises.
5) Improve math skills, focusing on subtraction.
6) Match the pictures to the cards and build picture-word skills.

21320.name: Mini-Combat
21320.description:
Mini Combat is a generic rule set for massive battles using small scale miniatures. The rules are generic enough to play historical, fantasy and sci-fi battles. It is also possible to play across genres. How would fantasy Orcs fare against the American Confederate army or WWII Nazis against the Alien horde? These rules can be used stand alone where you can pick and choose what sections you will use or they can be used with Source books that define the rules, army lists and objectives of the battles. The miniature scale was designed for 1:300 (6mm) to 1:1000 (2mm) although we have played with 1:185 (10mm) for Fantasy and 1:5000 for Naval combat.

What you need to play:
In addition to the rules, you will need figures to represent each side, at least two six sided dice (D6) and a ruler or tape measure.

http://www.geocities.com/shaungamer88/mini.htm

21321.description:
Advanced Squad Leader accessory scenario and map pack concerning aspects of the great tank battle of Kursk in 1943.

Krasny Oktabyr-Kliuchi, Russia, 11 July 1943: After a long night of struggling to secure little more than a tentative hold on the north bank of the Psel, the Totenkopf’s Panzer Regiment received orders to expand the bridgehead and explore the Russian defensive positions in the region. Unbeknownst to them, the reinforced 95th Guards Rifle Division was moving into positions overlooking the village of Krasny Oktabyr. As the Germans moved up from the river’s edge, the two forces collided under a summer squall, mutual surprise giving way to ferocious fighting. The Russians charged through the rain into the midst of the German force. Fighting was at point blank range; tanks often shot each other at less than one hundred meters. Both sides lost several vehicles before they each fell back. The Germans aimed themselves at Hill 226.6, which clearly dominated the local landscape. This fight was only the first of several fought this day as the Russians struggled to hold them back...
21321.name: Hell's Bridgehead

21322.name: Citibank Worldwide Banking Game
21322.description: This game was designed for the First National City Bank of New York, which has since become Citibank. The objective of the game is to collect the cards representing the 7 banking services offered by the bank in 1964, Savings Account, Checking Account, Trust Service, Overseas Service, Personal Banking, Travelers Checks, and Loan Service. Once a player has collected he or she can declare CITIBANK at which point all of the players total up the dollar amounts on the cards that they have collected and the player with the highest total wins. Cards are collected by landing on spaces around the board after rolling. Once cards are collected they are placed face down on the table in front of the player.

21323.name: Criminal Tango
21323.description:
SIX detectives hunting the bandits in the city of "BELLA BALERNO".... who will capture most of the robbers ?
contents:
1 board map of BELLA BALERNO
27 gangsters
12 clues cards
24 action cards...

21324.description:
Players in turn enter new pieces on the board or move pieces already placed to capture opponent pieces (thus building stacks). Pieces on board must always be connected (i.e. adjacent to other pieces). When all pieces are placed and both players pass their turn in sequence, points are collected for pieces and stacks. The player with the higher score is declared winner. Abande can be played on a 37-space hexagonal board, a 7×7 orthogonal grid (with diagonals) and many other boards (even without a board at all).

Expansion: Abande²
21324.name: Abande

21325.name: Eco-Force: Guardians of Earth  Birds of North America
21325.description:
Eco-Force: Guardians of Earth (tm) card games allow 2-4 players to manage their eco-system by adding habitats and animals worth points during their turn.

Impact cards in the deck may allow other players to cause reduction in another players eco-system during play and thus reduce their total points. Defense cards are also in play and can reduce or block other players from harming your eco-system.

At the end of the pre-determined number of rounds, the player with the most points wins the game. And keep an eye out for that Special Migration....

21326.name: Spotta
21326.description: The board has a large picture of a leopard without spots. Before the game, players place black spots with a particular word (all of which make a phrase with the word "spot") face down. Players then draw cards with a word and must find the appropriate spot on the leopard.

21327.name: Wordmaster
21327.description:
Each player gets a grid on which each will write one's words. A specially designed roulette wheel that has seven balls is spun. Instead of the usual numbers, the roulette wheel has letters of the alphabet. Each letter of the alphabet has been assigned a value from one to ten points. Once the seven letters for the round have been determined, the players have a time limit to use those letters in words on their individual grids crossword-style. The player with the most points after a predetermined number of rounds is the winner.

In the official rules in the box-lid, it there is a single crossword grid that is shared by all players, each player taking turns adding to the grid.

21328.name: Spectrum
21328.description:
One player is red/orange/yellow and the other is green/blue/violet. The winner of the game who places down more of his or her tokens onto the playing board than the opposing player. Each color which is placed on the playing board must always touch an adjoining color in the correct sequence of the spectrum (red may only touch orange, green may only touch yellow and blue, and so on).
The game starts with each player playing their six extreme tiles (red and violet) anywhere on the board, not touching each other. It is from this start the remaining tiles are played.
There is an alternate set of simpler rules for younger children.

21329.description: Rules expansion for the game Bonnie Blue. This expansion adds rules for playing games in World War 1.
21329.name: Bonnie Blue vid fronten

21331.name: Quip It!
21331.description:
From the publisher:

Where does your mind go when you witness life's stranger than fiction moments? Find out when you play Quip It!, where players take turns trying to guess which player wrote which quip for bizarre pictures, unusual film clips and other on-screen oddities. The more right guesses you make, the more points you score and the more points you score, the better. Be spontaneous, be unpredictable, be edgy-it doesn't matter, so long as you Quip It! good.

21332.description:
FlipQuest is an exciting role-playing, collectible card game, where you build the gameboard as you play.

Play alone or join your friends, and defeat Orcs, Dragons, and other powerful creatures using wits, skills, and awesome magical weapons, in FlipQuest, the exciting, innovative role-playing card game where players build the game board as they play from unique card decks. Each FlipQuest adventure deck contains a separate, stand-alone game for 1-4 players, and can be combined for more characters, treasures, and monsters.
21332.name: FlipQuest: "The Test" – A Thief's Quest

21333.description:
FlipQuest is an exciting role-playing, collectible card game, where you build the gameboard as you play.

Play alone or join your friends, and defeat Orcs, Dragons, and other powerful creatures using wits, skills, and awesome magical weapons, in FlipQuest, the exciting, innovative role-playing card game where players build the game board as they play from unique card decks. Each FlipQuest adventure deck contains a separate, stand-alone game for 1-4 players, and can be combined for more characters, treasures, and monsters.

http://www3.sympatico.ca/shadowcraft/
21333.name: FlipQuest: Quest for the Princess' Crystal

21334.name: Slings and Stones
21334.description:
Slings and Stones is a strategy boardgame which uses a standard checkerboard with chess and checkers pieces. It can easily be learned and played in a few short minutes, but mastery of the game will take much longer. Each and every move can have huge ramifications, and players will find it extremely difficult to plan more than a couple of rounds in advance.

I stumbled upon this game while skimming through some old journals I found in my grandfather�s attic. The rules were gleaned from Kardon's writings on the Muighar tribes, and I've tried my best to keep them authentic. However, as Kardon's description of the rules are not very clear, this version may vary slightly from that of antiquity.

As most of you probably don't have access to authentic Muighar Slings and Stones pieces or boards, I've taken the liberty of finding some substitutions. This game can played using a chess board, with 4 pawns and 12 checkers. Pawns represent the slings, and checkers represent the stones.

http://www.darkshadowgames.com/Epic_Registration/register.ht...
(Click "Download SLINGS.ZIP" for rules and bits)

Online Play


Super Duper Games

21335.name: Epic: Warlords
21335.description:
Epic: Warlords is a strategy wargame of a vast scope, dealing with the rise and fall of civilizations over hundreds of years, and the terrible battles and wars between the races of Elves, Goblins, Dwarves, and Man.

Epic: Warlords depicts an epic war between the ancient races of Man, Elves, Goblins and others for the domination of the world. The game takes place over the course of centuries or even millennia. But it is at the scale where even within this lengthy time frame, individual heroes and individual actions can leave an impact certain to give birth to legends.

This game involves many campaigns, all of indefinite length, within a larger round that involves the growth of populations and cities. And although armies may be large, individuals stand out due to leadership, artifacts, and miracles. At points in the game, you may wonder, 'just how did one hero defeat 3 units of my armies?' But use as reference - rather than the real world - the myths of Hercules, Odysseus, and King Arthur, or the fantasy stories 'The Lord of the Rings' and 'Conan the Barbarian' (at the end of which Conan and a friend kill about 50 mounted enemy knights).

http://www.darkshadowgames.com/Epic_Registration/register.ht...
(Click "Download EPIC.ZIP" for rules and bits)

21336.description:
This is a wargame on the battles of Imphal and Kohima 1944.

This review first appeared in IPW, the newsletter for all discount games club members. Contact colin@allusedgames.demon.co.uk for details.


On the 6th March, 1944, the last great ground campaign of the Pacific theater began. The Japanese launched a two pronged thrust against the allied held towns of Kohima and Imphal. Both towns were allied forward supply dumps and the Japanese were intent upon capturing their contents.
The offensive came as a great surprise, as allied Intelligence had suggested an attack on this scale was beyond Japanese capabilities.

Historically, both locations were surrounded, but Imphal was reinforced and supplied by air. Neither town fell and they were both relieved by allied troops advancing from the railhead at Dimapur, further South West. At the time of writing, this is the only simulation I know of that covers the entire campaign at an operational scale.

A game turn commences with the British and Japanese players checking supply. The British player has Supply Dumps, each with its own number of supply points recorded on a track on the map. Units trace supply to these dumps and the points thereby consumed are subtracted from the track record. The Japanese are automatically in supply for the first two game turns. From turns three to eight, however, they must trace supply in a similar manner to the British, except that supply points are held by their HQ units rather than in supply dumps. These, being mobile, are more flexible.

The Japanese continue to trace supply after turn eight in the same manner, but supply points become rather scarce. Units without supply have both movement and combat factors halved and cannot attack. The exceptions are the three Japanese allied units of the Indian National Army, who are eliminated after two turns without supply. The supply rules for this game are its most complex procedure, but are easily manageable for an experienced player. Japanese movement and combat follow. Movement uses standard wargame practice, though a lot of the terrain on the map is tough going.

Combat also holds no real surprises, being based on odds adjusted by terrain. Combat results are exchanges, retreats and eliminations. On the first turn, the Japanese get a second movement phase after combat, simulating the initial advantage of surprise.

British movement and combat follow, after which any British reinforcements are added to the pool of such units held off map. The British player then gets to transfer supply points between dumps or transport points from an inexhaustible supply dump off map to those on.
The catch is that these same rail and air resources are also required to transport reinforcements on to the map. These, of course, are no good without supply, and vice versa.

Finally, Japanese reinforcements are added to the map and the game turn is over.

Little exists in the manner of Special rules. Engineers assist units in assaults across rivers, but not, strangely, against fortified lines. Artillery have a two hex range and British armored cavalry can retreat before combat in certain circumstances. Victory is determined by the number of towns and cities held by the Japanese player at games end and each players unit losses.

Despite being published back in 1975, March on India 1944 remains a good game whose rules are remarkably playable. Not suitable for beginners, but eminently playable solo, its subject has been sadly overlooked by game designers ever since. In my opinion, on the strength of this previous worthy offering, the subject deserves a more up to date treatment to test the mettle of the current crop of designers. Until then, seek out a copy of this one. You won't be disappointed.

Alan Sharif
21336.name: March on India 1944

21337.description:
This is a wargame on the final Allied and Soviet offensives to take Nazi Germany in 1945. It has two scenarios, February 1945 and the Downfall (April 1945) scenarios.

Published in JagdPanther magazine #9
21337.name: Goetterdaemmerung: The Fall of Nazi Germany 1945

21338.description:
From the DVG web site:

Overview:
Elves Under Hoof is a light-hearted game of combat at the North Pole. It seems the elves have opened up a crate of ultra-violent video games and played them all night. By morning they had been turned into mindless zombie elves bent on destruction.

Now, it is up to your team of heroic reindeer to gather weapons and battle the crazed elves to save the day!

Key Points:
- Very easy to play.
- Fun for all ages.
- Armed reindeer take on the evil elves.
- Just in time for the holidays!
(if it is around holiday time when you are reading this)
- Just the thing to remind you of Christmas!
(if it is not holiday time when you are reading this)
- 4 Scenarios: An Igloo Too Far, Saving Private Reindeer, E-Day, and The Big Red One

Component List:
- Expensive Player Help Sheet
- One Sheet of Full Color counters
- Very cute full-color Map
- Humor-filled rulebook

Target Audience:
This is a great game for both wargamers and non-gamers alike. The game is fast and easy to understand and who doesn’t like throwing hand grenades at elves?

Game Formats:
PDF Download
21338.name: Elves Under Hoof

21339.name: Reflex
21339.description: First player selects a desired pattern or combination on the three dice. The three dice are rolled, and if the combination matches, the first player to drive his "scorer" up the wire loop to the center gets the point.

21340.name: The Mensa Boardgames Pack
21340.description:
A book from Mensa, published by Barnes and Noble (or by Index in the UK), that includes several boards and pieces.

The book contains a number of games:

All Change! - a one player "game" (actually a puzzle),

Puzzle Piracy - A variant of Sorry where players landing on certain squares have to answer Mensa questions,

various Chess problems,

various peg solitaire problems,

Space Strategy Game - an abstract capture game with three different types of pieces on a board consisting of four concentric rings,

three solitaire peg problems by Henry Dudeney,

crossword puzzles,

and a series of Mensa puzzles.

Only Puzzle Piracy and Space Strategy Game could really be considered "board games" in the classic sense.

21341.name: Cowboys and Indians
21341.description:
An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

This game is designed to utilize those plastic cowboy and Indians lying around your house and put them to use in an entry-level wargame.

Goal: Capture your opponent's Fort or Village.

21342.description: Players try to take tricks to capture the ingredients necessary to complete their secret recipe. Taking a trick requires playing a high card, but if cards are tied, the player who played that value last gets the trick--so there is a HUGE disadvantage in going first.
21342.name: The Great Chili Cookoff

21343.name: Graverobbers
21343.description: Players are trying to save (or destroy) graves in 1880s London cemeteries. Players have secret objectives--playing cards makes the objectives more attainable, BUT--you score points based on cards still in hand when the game is done (so the more you play, the less you score). Worse still, half the cards help, the other half hurt your scoring--but to ditch the bad cards, you have to play them...and potentially hurt your chances of winning in the first place!! Very tricky. (from Jolly Roger Games as reported on boardgamenews.com)

21344.description:
An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

Goal of the Game: The player wins who first connects his opposing sides of the board.

Each player 'owns' two opposing sides of the board. It is advised to mark the sides of each player (at least by placing all the pieces of the players on his sides only). The players may decide whether they want to place the board between them with the corners facing to them or whether they want to sit at an right angle with the sides toward them.

At the start of play the board is empty. One player starts the game. The play then alternates.

At each move the player whose turn it is has three options of play:


He can enter one of his pieces onto the board;
Move on of his pieces on the board; or
Capture an opposing piece with one of his own pieces on the board.


The player wins the game who is the first to get an uninterrupted line from one of his own sides of the board to his other (opposing) side.
21344.name: Apex

21346.description:
Nannon is a reduction of Backgammon to a super-quick game. Nannon reduces the basic concepts of Backgammon to the smallest feasible combination that still retains the idea of Backgammon.

For instance:

Rather than having "stacks" of men on each position, Nannon allows only one man per spot.
Since you can't "stack" men, contiguous groups of 2 or all 3 men of the same team can't be hit.
Each player has only three men, as opposed to the 15 of Backgammon.
Each player gets one die, rather than getting to use two. (Nannon makes use of the fact that each player has her own die.)
The board only has six positions, instead of 24.

Nannon does, however, still provide a doubling cube, which is rather relevant since the individual games of Nannon are so much shorter than those of Backgammon.
21346.name: Nannon

21347.name: The New Kid's Choices Board Game
21347.description:
Applying Biblical Principles to Everyday Situations

You wanted a stereo CD player for your birthday, and made sure that your grandparents knew it. They've given you an encyclopedia program for the family computer instead. What will you say to them?

A student in charge of lunch tickets has given you too many tickets for the money you gave him. What will you do with the extra tickets?

You don't like the clothes your mom buys for you. You prefer denim and T-shirts. What will you tell her?

Making the right choice can be tough. But with the help of Kid's Choices, learning to make the best decisions becomes exciting entertainment!

Grab your family or your friends (or both!) and get ready to come face to face with some of life's toughest decisions, including those involving friendship, forgiveness and obedience. Learn how to base all your decision making on biblical principles (twenty in all, supported by several verses from the popular NIV® translation of the Bible).

Designed for Ages 6 - 12, The New Kid's Choices is great game play for three to six players, and can also be played in teams. Includes colorful game board, six player markers, 150 dilemma cards, 10 principle cards and an instruction/reference booklet.

108422.name: Les Aventuriers du rail à Lyon (fan expansion to Ticket to Ride)

boardgamehonor.8859: 2006 Golden Geek Best Family Board Game Nominee

21348.description:
Ticket to Ride: Märklin is the third installment in Days of Wonder's best-selling Ticket to Ride series. The board for Märklin is based on a map of Germany and each individual card in the deck depicts a different Märklin Trains model. A DVD introducing players to the Märklin line of model trains is included [Edit: DVD no longer included in recent runs.]

Märklin is a heavier version in the TTR series, allowing players to not only travel from city to city but also from cities to countries. A new mechanic is also introduced in the form of passengers and merchandise tokens. When the game is set-up a series of merchandise values worth victory points are placed on nominated cities. The values of these tokens diminish when multiple tokens are present within a single city, requiring players to move quickly to capture the higher valued tokens.

These tokens can be collected by the players by placing their Passengers (3 per player), which can be achieved at the end of a turn in which a player lays trains to enter the city in question. Once a passenger is in play a player can forfeit their regular turn to move a passenger. Moving along a player's own train network comes at no cost and allows a player to take the top merchandise token from each city that is passed through. A passenger can also move along sections of track featuring other players trains but a passenger card must be paid each time this occurs to do so.

The player who completes the most destination tickets receives a 10 point bonus (instead of the base game's longest route bonus).
21348.name: Ticket to Ride: Märklin

21349.name: Dominox
21349.description:
An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

Dominox is played on a standard Chess/Checkers board using a standard set of Domino tiles. Only tiles with 0 to 6 dots are used. One player is designated 'white' while the other is 'black.' The players take turn placing tiles on the board, starting with the player who is dealt the lowest numbered double-tile, who must place this a his first move.

Tiles are placed according to the following restrictions:

* A tile must be placed such that it spans two squares (i.e., one half of the tile is on a black square and the other half is on a white).
* No two tiles can share a square.
* If a tile is placed next to another tile, the number of dots on the touching tile-end(s) must match that of its (their) neighbour. If a tile-end is next to several other tile-ends, only one of these need to match.

When there are no un-drawn tiles left and two passes in a row occur (i.e., both players pass), the game ends. At this point, the unfilled areas on the board are scored: Each connected unfilled area on the board counts to the color that is in majority in that area. If there is the same number of black and white squares, no player gets points for the area.

The player with the most points wins.

21350.name: Fire Drill
21350.description:
In Fire Drill, each player takes turns placing one of their pieces on any square on the board. The only limitation is that each piece must be at least one square away from a piece of the same color. Once all the pieces have been placed on the board, the starting player chooses any of his pieces to move. Play then alternates between opponents, each moving one of their own pieces. Pieces are moved in the fashion of the robots in Ricochet Robots. A piece travels in a straight line until it hits a wall or another piece, at which time it can turn left, right, or stop. A piece may make any number of turns and travel any distance in a turn, but once it stops, play proceeds to the next player.

The first player to align four of his pieces in a row orthogonally wins.

21351.name: Freeze
21351.description:
An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

Player 1 owns the black checkers, while player 2 owns the red checkers. Opponents alternate turns, as in most games. A 'king' is defined as in the game of Checkers: it is a stack of two checkers, of the same color. Kings cannot move but can be captured.

On his turn, a player chooses one of his own checkers to move. Moves are made vertically or horizontally, but not diagonally. A single move consists of picking up the chosen checker, jumping it over an opponent's checker or king (the jumped checker or king must be directly above, below, left, or right of the moving checker), and landing on an unoccupied square on the other side of the jumped checker. The jumped checker or king is then captured (removed from the board). On the same turn, a player may (but is not required to) continue moving this chosen checker in this way, until that checker cannot capture any more. A checker can only move if in so doing it captures an opponent's checker or king.

On his turn, after he has finished capturing, a player may use the checkers which he has just captured to transform some of his opponent's checkers into kings, by placing a single captured checker on top of a checker of the same color which is still on the board. The two checkers from a captured king can be used to make two new kings. A player can make as many kings on his turn as he has captured checkers.

The loser is the first player not able to move on his turn.

21352.name: President
21352.description:
An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

The worst fear of a Secret Service Agent is when the President of the US decides to leave an established motorcade and work the crowd. In this game, one player plays the President and his two Secret Service Agents and the other represents a crowd with an unknown assassin. Can you get the President through the crowd alive?

The President starts in one of the two center squares on one side of the board. He then places one Secret Service Agent on each side of the President. The crowd starts with 6 crowd members anywhere on the opposite half of the board.

Goal: The President player must exit from one of the two center squares on the opposite side of the board. The crowd player must assassinate the President.

21353.name: Everest
21353.description:
This is a game for a standard piecepack.

Every year on the summer solstice the male yeti in the Himalayas have a contest to determine which one will be the head of the pack for the next year. This contest consists of a game of “King of the Hill” combined with a snowball fight. A yeti wins by being the sole occupant of the mountain peak for a full round of the game. Avoid the snowballs and don't fall off the cliffs.

This game uses a multi-level board of stacked tiles as the mountain and a Roborally like programmed movement system.

21356.name: The Simpsons: Homer's Trivia Game
21356.description:
(From the box, weird punctuation and grammar preserved)

The Simpsons: Homer's Trivia Game

Hello, I'm Homer J. Simpson! Everybody knows that I have only two hairs on the top of my head (d'oh!) But do you know why I lost most of my hair? Or why my frumpy, old maid of a sister-in-law Selma has no sense of smell or taste? No? Well, don't fret like that pansy Flanders! (The answers are below!) Inside this box are lots more questions about Springfield's number one father, me.

You can compete with your friends, or other Simpson trivia-geeks (you know the type I'm talking about!) See who knows more about me (and what's more important than that?). It's more more fun than "Deviled-egg Nite" at Moe's Tavern!

And guess what? The game comes with a Simpsons cast poster. Whoo-hoo!

Answers:
Homer lost more and more hair each time one of his children were born
Selma lost her sense of taste and smell when a bottle rocket shot up her nose

21357.description:
It adds a musical theme for the series of Team Work Original games. It can be played as an expansion or stand-alone.

Expands:

Team Work Original
21357.name: Team Work: Musik

21358.description:
From the publisher:

Welcome to a revolution in gaming! Savage Worlds is a merger of the best ideas in roleplaying and miniature games!

What's so revolutionary? We're glad you asked!

It's Fast! Savage Worlds is the fastest and easiest fully-detailed roleplaying game you'll ever play! You can fight out massive battles quickly and easily with your heroes, allies and minions in one simple, fast-playing system!

It's Furious! Characters gain awesome new abilities quickly, raising their attributes and skills and gaining powerful and exciting new Edges!

It's Fun! Savage Worlds was designed to be a Game Master's dream! GMs can write adventures, create new villains and monsters, and run epic tales, all without lots of bookkeeping. And you won't need computer programs, three rule books, and a half-dozen setting books to do it. You'll find everything you need right here and in the Savage Setting of your choice!

It's also a Miniatures Game! Savage Worlds works as a miniatures battle game as well as an RPG. That means you can fight out your heroes epic battles to save the world right on the table-top! Or you can play a competitive battle with troops of your own design!

It's Complete! Savage Worlds was designed to be used with any genre from swashbuckling pirates to superheroes and sci-fi. Inside you'll find complete and simple rules for epic heroes, vehicles, chases, magic, superpowers, mass battles, skirmishes, and even guidelines for designing your own races and worlds!

Expanded by:

Tour of Darkness




As an RPG:
Savage Worlds can also be played strictly as a roleplaying game, and thus also exists as an rpggeek rpg entry.
21358.name: Savage Worlds

21359.name: The Senior Prom Game
21359.description:
"All the thrills of a social season and a chance to be a .... Prom Queen"

A very cheaply made game by 'Built Rite'. The Senior Prom Game is a simple roll and move game for children. The game board is made out of thin cardboard and features 2 different tracks to move around depending on an initial spin with the spinner. Even the playing tokens are made out of cheap cardboard.

Some out of date and stereo-typical items are found on the game board including....

"Meet new boy at game. Wow! Run ahead 3 spaces."

"Dance with T.V. idol at sock hop. Move ahead 6 spaces."

"Study for finals with boy friend. Move ahead 2 spaces."

21360.description:
From the website:
In 1990, Saddam Hussein engineered the invasion and occupation of Kuwait, giving Iraq control of 24% of the world's oil supplies. January 1991, The United States and her allies launch Desert Shield and Desert Storm in an effort to remove the brutal dictator's forces from Kuwait. The First Gulf War was underway.

With the pieces from your "Axis & Allies" games and some others, then YOU can embark upon this 'Global' encounter. No longer is it restricted BY just the actual "Area of Operations", as the entire WORLD with 'this' has their 'say' for things. Declare a "Jihad!", tout your "Scientolo-dogma", "Kill for OIL!", it could ALL be there, so YOU 'be' there or be-hind!
21360.name: Rune Blade's Gulf War 1991

21361.name: Monopoly: U.S. Space Program
21361.description: This is a US Space Program flavored version of the classic board game. It comes with 8 customized tokens (satellite, astronaut, shuttle, lunar rover, space capsule, lunar lander, the Hubble, or the Mars Sojourner), a board with space program related destinations, hangars and space centers instead of houses and hotels, and Moon and Earth cards. It also features a complete mission manual with additional information on the US Space Program.

21362.name: Batman: The Game
21362.description: This is a game based in the 1989 movie starring Jack Nicholson and Michael Keaton, whose images feature in the graphics of the gameboard. Players can choose to be either a "Batman" or a "Joker", which determines their starting places and objectives. Batman must travel from Wayne Manor to the Batcave, and Joker must travel from Grissom's Apartment to Axis Chemical. Upon arrival, a Destination card is chosen, and the first player to reach their destination wins. There are cards drawn on various spaces (power, direction, and battle) that give advantages and players can battle an opposite character type with a die roll-vs-die roll contest to gain extra moves and cards.

21363.description:
Following Suit is a simple trick-taking game. The object is to collect as many points as possible in a single suit. The game is played in several rounds and the first player to reach 400 points wins.

Following Suit was one of the simultaneous-play games which began with Lamarckian Poker (published by GAMES Magazine in 1997 and previously free on the Cheapass website) and continued with Last Man Standing and Starbase Jeff. Following Suit was first published in Game Trade Monthly in 2000.
21363.name: Following Suit

21364.name: A.D. 1706, Le Siège de Turin
21364.description:
There are two different games inside the box: one on the field battle of Torino (7/9/1706) fought before the city and the other for the siege of the Cittadella (26/7 - 7/9/1706)itself.

The quality of the maps is not very high, while the counters (more than 500) are a work of art, with splendid reproduction of the period uniforms.
The rules are of medium complexity and of the usual kind for the field battle, while they seem very peculiar for the siege battle itself.

21365.name: Luchthavenspel Schiphol
21365.description:
Players travel back and forth to Schiphol.

The person arriving back first wins.

Part of the game operates on the airport itself. After moving through check-in and security checks the player 'flies' to a destination and then flies back.
Has features in the game in order to try and stall or slow down the other players.
