21366.name: RPGQuest: The Knights Templar
21366.description:
A very colorful mixture of RPG and Boardgame, this Brazilian game is designed for children of Ages 8 - 14 as an introduction to miniature games.

The game has rules for miniature battles between two or more participants. As in most miniatures games, players build an army with the same number of recruitment points (with each miniature having a different point value), then take turns moving and attacking until the opponent's forces are dead, withdrawn, or your pre-determined time limit expires.

The basic game has 11 classes to choose from, over 170 paper fold-out miniatures, 2 82x55cm colored maps and dozens of props.

The game is based on the Knights Templar´s history and mythology

boardgamecompilation.29549: Saint Petersburg: New Society & Banquet Expansion

21367.description:
This expansion for Saint Petersburg consists of 12 new cards (3 normal and 9 special) that add more special abilities to the game.

The expansion was originally published in the December 2005 issue of Spielbox magazine.

Rio Grande Games has bundled this into the Saint Petersburg: New Society & Banquet Expansion.

Expands:

Saint Petersburg
21367.name: Saint Petersburg: The Banquet

21369.name: The Two Ocean War
21369.description:
Rare add-on for Avalon Hill's 'War at Sea (second edition)' and 'Victory in the Pacific' series but also a standalone game.

Includes (688) 1" square styrene counters that can be used with the original games or with the included (4) maps and a (48) page rulebook for combined global game. The maps are 21" x 27" and there are two Pacific and two Atlantic maps with a total of 39 areas.

As a standalone game, The Two Ocean War allows double-blind player movement via two copies of the Atlantic and Pacific theater maps. During the movement phase, players place their fleets on their own game boards, unaware of the other player's moves. Once moves are completed, both players go area by area on both maps, resolving battles between fleets placed in the same areas on the two different maps and to resolve combat and determine victory points awarded for each sea zone. Combat is similar to the Avalon Hill sea games, using six-sided dice. Rolls of 1-4 are no effect, 5 is a disable (ship returns to port), 6 is a hit causing a subsequent die roll for amount of damage.

The game is superior to the Avalon Hill sea games in some regards. Highlights include larger fleets (CL-class ships for all nations are represented in addition to the other ship classes in the AH games), more sea zones, and the blind movement resulting in often surprising battle lineups in particular sea zones. Additional rules let small ships torpedo big ones under certain conditions, and since the game represents fleets worldwide, there are opportunities for some Axis ships to change theaters just as the Allied ships can.

21370.description:
The Africa Edition has at present the best pre-constructed starters for History of War which are really a recommendation for new customers.

Although the Africa Edition consists of two pre-constructed decks for two players, the cards can of course be combined with all the other expansions of History of War. So the game - and all its expansions - can be played in multi-player sessions. The number of players may range from 2 - ?. There is no real limit, but the available place on most tables and the handling of some game mechanics usually do limit the player number to 6. Official multi-player rules don´t clarify that. It is recommended to play in two factions (axis and allies) with even player numbers - so 2, 4 or 6 players is best.
21370.name: History of War: Africa Edition

21371.description:
An expansion to the Federation Commander: Klingon Border with 16 new ships (full color CGI graphics 1" counters, full color laminated ship diagrams) and several new scenarios plus two new map panels with full color planets! Part of the Federation Commander Series.

New ship cards include:

Juggernaut (monster)
Orion Pirate Salvage Ship
Orion Pirate Light Raider
Tholian Destroyer
Free Trader (2 printed on each side)
Klingon D5W New Cruiser
Klingon D5 War Cruiser
Klingon E4 Light Frigate
Federation Battlecruiser (BCJ-type w/ 6 torpedoes)
Federation Police Cutter
Kzinti Medium Cruiser
Kzinti Dreadnought
Kzinti Heavy Battlecruiser
Kzinti Light Cruiser
Kzinti War Destroyer
Kzinti New Heavy Cruiser




1" counters for all of these (multiple counters for most smaller ships), as well as counters for:

Federation CF (Fast Cruiser)
Klingon FD7 (Fast Cruiser)
Kzinti CF (Fast Cruiser)
Kzinti NCC (New Command Cruiser)




Home Page: http://www.federationcommander.com/
21371.name: Federation Commander:  Klingon Attack

21372.description:
An expansion to Federation Commander: Romulan Border adding new ships and scenarios. Part of the Federation Commander Series.

Publisher's Home Page: http://www.federationcommander.com/

Expands:

Federation Commander: Romulan Border
21372.name: Federation Commander:  Romulan Attack

21373.description:
New captains are sent to fight pirates.
Bold captains are sent to fight Klingons.
Only the clever Captains are sent to fight the crafty cloaked Romulans!

From the designer of Star Fleet Battles and Federation & Empire, Federation Commander: Romulan Border is a fast-moving game of starship combat in the Star Fleet Universe. This is not an 'introduction' to some other title. This is a product in an entirely new direction for the Star Fleet Universe, featuring production values expected by 21st-century gamers - mounted game maps, laminated full-color ship cards, full color counters, and laminated full-color play aids.

This is the second base set in the Federation Commander Series (Federation Commander: Klingon Border being the other).
This is a complete game and does not require any other products for use. All other Federation Commander Products will work with Romulan Border.
Components: 60-page Rev-4 rulebook, 216 half-inch and 20 one-inch full color die cut playing pieces, four full-color double-sided laminated player reference cards, sixteen full color double-sided laminated ship cards, six 8.5x11 hard-mounted double-sided map panels, two dice, paper clips for energy track, wipe-off marker. Improvements over Klingon Border: Higher-quality maps (now used in both products), real wipe-off marker, latest revision rulebook, expanded Sequence of Play.

It is far more than just "SFB Lite." It uses the best concepts from the best-selling space combat game of all time with Euro-Game production values and ease of play.

Key points include:

A typical duel takes one hour
The largest fleet battles take four hours, not four days.
Energy is spent "on the fly" via a marker on a sliding scale.
Ship diagrams are laminated (multiple use, no photocopies!).
Color coded charts and ship cards make it easier remembering what goes where.
Expansions include more ships, more scenarios, more maps - not complex new rules.




Publisher's home page for this game: www.federationcommander.com
21373.name: Federation Commander:  Romulan Border

21374.name: Napoleon Dynamite: It's Pretty Much My Favorite Animal Game
21374.description:
"It's pretty much my favorite animal. It's like a lion and a tiger mixed ... bred for its skills in magic."

If you drew a liger, would someone be able to guess that you combined a lion and a tiger to create it?

On your turn take two cards - each with a different animal name - and draw a combination animal - fast. If you get your teammates to guess what two animals you used, you move ahead on the game board. Heck, yes.

Land on Uncle Rico - IDIOT! - and you've got to show your next animal throwing a football. Land on Kip - Geez, I think you ripped my mole off! - and you have to combine THREE animals next time you draw.

The first player to get to the finish space wins.

21375.name: Hive Alive
21375.description:
Can your fleet of numbered bees infiltrate the enemy hive and "buzz" the Queen Bee?
Higher numbered bees outrank lower ones. With a single "buzz," or touch, they move remove lesser bees from the hive. At number zero, the Queen Bee is practically defenseless.
Protect your Queen Bee from attack!
Steer clear of the dreaded fungus!
Watch out for the deadly Killer Bee!

Math skills covered: inequalities (greater than, less than), fractions, decimals, negative numbers, and place value.

This game is meant for use in grade 2 mathematics classrooms and beyond. The game is to be played by two players at a time. Players try to protect their queen bee from attack; steer clear of the black fungus; and avoid the deadly killer bee. Each player has nine worker bees with a whole number, fraction, or decimal value, one queen bee, and one killer bee. Players attack other bees of unknown value, and the bee with the higher value survives. Whoever captures their opponent's queen bee wins. Mathematics skills covered include inequalities; fractions; decimals; negative numbers; and place value. The game contains a game board, bee value cards, and playing piece stands.

21376.name: James Bond 007: Das Agentenspiel
21376.description: Players are secret agents who try to be the one who defeats the evil guys located on an island in the center of the board. To do this they've to arrive there with a certain (secret) combination of microfilms (every player starts with 10 microfilms in his own color - different colors can be acquired by fighting other players). Agents travel around the board rolling a die and using transportation cards to acquire equipment cards and transportation cards to fight other players. Fights are resolved by secretly choosing up to two equipment cards - better equipment (total number) wins.

21377.name: Ferrari Challenge
21377.description:
Before the race starts choose the setup of your car and the driver abilities guessing the right tires and the best engine setup to beat other players.

Play your cards and bring your car to the victory.
Every race will be different.

Contents:
94 modular elements to build every circuit you can dream of.
42 numbered chits
60 cards
3 dice
8 plastic cars in different colors
rules

21378.description: Zargo's Lords 2 is an expansion for Zargo's Lords. It adds 2 new people (the Aracnids people and its web-laying giant spiders, retiarii and poisoned arrows-firers, and the Amazons , a people of shapeshifters and light infantry able to cross enemy zones of control unnoticed), more cities for each people, Magic rules and new rules that make the game shorter and more fierce, forcing players to the offensive even at the beginning of the game.
21378.name: Zargo's Lords 2: Expansion Pack

21379.name: Taxicab
21379.description:
A game for the piecepack.

Operate a Taxicab in Pp City to earn more money then the other drivers in the Pp City "Best Taxi Driver" contest. This is a pick-up-and-delivery game with randomly generated passenger pick-up and destination addresses.

21380.description:
In Conquest of the Fallen Lands, you and your fellow players have a task to free a land invaded by vile hordes of monsters, and win back the treasures they plundered.

The game board is composed of hex tiles representing orc scouting parties, encampments, fortifications, dragons, etc. Each tile has a difficulty level.

Players take turns conquering these tiles by playing troop cards on them. Each conquered tile creates new opportunities to tackle tougher tiles around it, both for you and your opponents (so you have to be careful!).

Conquering a tile gets you a reward equal to its difficulty level. This money is used in the game to purchase assets and abilities, and it is also used to determine who has won this game, once it's over.

A number of magic cards introduce a variety of special effects and abilities that can greatly benefit the players.

The game includes two rule sets, Normal and Advanced, that play very differently:

The Normal game is very accessible; it is a lighter game that plays with little downtime and yet has a lot of strategic depth.
The Advanced rules lead to a more complex game that can sometimes be a bit of a brain burner. It also moves at a much slower pace.
21380.name: Conquest of the Fallen Lands

21381.name: Sizzletoad!
21381.description:
You've just stumbled onto a small secret pond, hidden right in your own neighborhood. Three odd little creatures and their frog-friends are playing, and whatever their game is it's good! There's a duck made of paper, a bug trapped in a rock, and a toad spitting sparks from its tongue.

They're all squealing and jumping, leap-frogging and bumping, and racing the pond; oh what fun! Such tumbling and flapping and sparking and quacking; how you'd love to join the confusion. Then they all see you watching and ask you to play, and assure you it's not an intrusion.

Sizzletoad! is the game for two to four players (ages 5 and up) that combines rock-paper-scissors and tic-tac-toe with an exciting leap-frog race around the pond! There's a nice bluffing element as well (especially in the 2-player version).

Players duel with each other in rock-paper-scissors style using their 12-card hands of Fossilticks, Paperducks, and Sizzletoads to decide which player will be able to put cards on the lily pad pond, make a tic-tac-toe, and score the most victory points.

During the race around the pond the excitement builds as the players speed closer and closer to the flower at the finish-line! Care for a game of Sizzletoad! anyone?

This is a great game for parents to play with their kids when they're looking for a bit more variation and strategy than say, "Candy Land" or the like.

Here's a quick "How to Play" summary for the two-player game:

In a two player game, of Sizzletoad! the players shuffle and split the deck (which is filled with an equal number of Sizzletoads, Fossilticks, and Paperducks.)

Each round a single card is compared between the players and the winner of the duel puts either of those two cards onto the lily-pad tic-tac-toe grid of the board. The other card goes into that player's discard pile.

When one of the players places a matching "3-in-a-row" card on the tic-tac-toe grid, the other player counts the cards in his/her own discard pile, scores one point for each card and moves his/her game piece around the board by that many pips, then hands his/her cards over to the maker of the tic-tac-toe.

The maker of the tic-tac-toe then puts those cards into his/her own discard pile and adds them all up, scoring one point for each card and also moving his/her game piece around the board by that many pips.

All of the cards are then shuffled, re-dealt, and the players have another duel. The players continue dueling and adding cards to the board and their own discard piles and moving their game pieces around the numbered pips on the board.

The winner is the player who makes it all the way around the board onto or past the flowered lily-pad before the other player.

With easy game play, this solid game is a fine addition to any "children's'" game library.

Remember: Sizzletoad-beats-Paperduck-which-beats-Fossiltick-which-beats-Sizzletoad!

Sizzletoad! by Mindspan Labs (previously WizerGames) is Made in the USA

Mindspan Labs Digital has released a 1 and 2 player app version of Sizzletoad! that is now available in the Apple app store.

21382.name: In10sity
21382.description: A trivia game for everyone! 700 fascinating trivia questions where every answer is a number between 1 and 10. Make big moves forward if your answer is correct. Take small steps if you're within one. Get it wrong and you'll have to move backwards. Be the first around the track and win!

21383.description: Number 73 of edition Spielbox, issue 6 in 2005. Each player has the same set of 8 cards. These cards are placed around cauldrons to get points. The problem is - nobody nows which cauldrons are going to count at the end of the game.
21383.name: Hexenkessel

21384.description:
This expansion for Memoir '44 takes you to the Pacific Theater, complete with a new Japanese army, new terrains and new command rules for the Imperial Japanese Army and the US marines.

Part of the Memoir '44 series.

Expands:

Memoir '44
21384.name: Memoir '44: Pacific Theater

21385.description:
The Tower is the fourth major expansion for the Carcassonne game. Tower segments are added to the game, as well as some new actions. Instead of placing a Meeple as usual on their turns, players can now either place a tower segment on a tile with a space for a tower, add a tower segment to a tower already standing, or place a Meeple on top of a tower (which "finishes" it).

Placing a tower segment allows you to capture other players' Meeples, so long as they are in view of the tower in an orthogonal direction. If the tower is 1 piece high, they can capture Meeples that are within 1 tile of the tower; if the tower is 2 pieces high, they can capture Meeples within 2 tiles of the tower; etc. Not only do players lose whatever they may have scored with that Meeple, but they also have to pay 3 victory points if they want to free their Meeple.

Part of the Carcassonne series.
21385.name: Carcassonne: The Tower

21386.description:
Fast-action family card game with a Science Fiction theme. Features a unique blend of strategy, skill, and chance.

Spaced Out is a fast-paced card game with exciting variables. "Cloning" is an exhilarating part of Spaced Out game play! Players are often on the edge of their seats, hoping to play out-of-turn, take extra turns, attack and defend against attacks. Utilize multiple scoring strategies. Every hand of SPACED OUT is unique, making the game enjoyable for different ages, size groups, and time-frames.
21386.name: Spaced Out

21387.description: Sub-titled: "Present Day Tactical Naval Combat". Beginning with an excellent introduction about the evolution of 'Ships' from the "Post WW-2" era up until the 'present'-(circa 1979), and with some possible 'future' contingents. This is a set of RULES for use in conjunction with "Modern Naval Miniatures"(or 'counters') up to a scale of '1/1200th'-although others can be adapted for use as well. This is slightly larger than the norm-('11'&-3/4 by '8'&-1/2) sized "Rulebook" compilation, of 70-pages in length, with a 'slick'-cover for the contents. There is a 'section' which details just what will be required to enable any "playings" for this. Interspersed within the "Rules" are some "Tables" for comparison & explanations, with 'examples' also being shown. From page '42' and on, there are various "Charts", "Tables", the "Tactical Data Display"-sheet 'example' provided, the 'Bibliography', "Designer's Notes", with the "Table of Contents" on the last back '2'-pages for this. The scale given is '1'-vessel per 'mini' OR "counter", '2'-minutes per Turn, '1'-inch = 2,000 yds(m)-can also be scaled where more room is permitted.
21387.name: Warship Commander 1967 to 1987

21388.description:
The game includes a 5 3/4", 4 1/2", by 1 1/2" box that includes a 11" x 17" game map, 3 pages of rules, 55 cut-out U.S. counters, 63 cut-out Japanese counters, 18 flag markers, and a D10. The game is a type of expansion for Axis and Allies, but it might be possible to use this with other games too. An alternative scenario simulates the battle as if the U.S. had not broken the Japanese code.

This expansion doesn't seem to be an official expansion.

Expands:

Axis & Allies
21388.name: Midway

boardgameimplementation.212830: The Game of Ports and Commerce

21389.description:
This game is very similar to the The Game of Authors. The biggest difference appears to be that the names of the missing set cards are not provided on at the bottom of each card. The game can be used to teach job names to children.

This game was designed in England and was originally published for the Great Exhibition by John Jaques & Sons. The outside of the box described the name as Happy Families while the inside of the box describes the name as Merry Families. Each quartet consists of four family members -- a father, a mother, a son, and a daughter. The fathers are Mr. Daub the Painter, Mr. Dough the Baker, Mr. Pill the Doctor, Mr. Sand the Grocer, Mr. Saw the Carpenter, Mr. Snip the Barber, Mr. Stain the Dyer, Mr. Smut the Sweep, Mr. Thread the Tailor, and Mr. Tub the Brewer.
21389.name: Happy Families

21390.name: Münzenfund und alte Knochen
21390.description: What is really stockpiled in museums all over the world? The people able to search the depots are interested in more than just Madonna sculptures or Biedermeier furniture. Real things are also hidden! Real mammoth bones, treasure chests, old toys and antique machines. Even parts of an old train can be found! A tactical dice game for three to six game players. The game features many very cool looking components.

21391.description: An abstract game that many can play with pleasure, because the rules are really elementary! Limited release at Essen in 1998. Players place colored chips to form specific score-generating patterns.
21391.name: Elementari

21392.name: Froggy Bottom
21392.description:
The frogs of Froggy Bottom are having a race to see who is the fastest. Each frog will visit all five of his home lily pads and return to his starting place. The frog that does this first is the winner!

The object of the game, which is designed for a standard piecepack, is to visit each lily pad of your color and return to your home. When a lily pad of your color is reached, it is flipped to show the number side. When all of your symbols have been turned over and your frog returns to its
home pad, you win.

Online Play


Super Duper Games

21393.name: Get Rich
21393.description:
The chess-like board is mostly water, with "islands" in the middle. Each player has a homeland in a corner of the board with 3 ports.

Units are naval vessels, aircraft, air/naval bases and construction units.

Players purchase units with money and fight it out their military units to become the richest player by the end of the game.

A full set includes:

4 fact sheets (purchase prices, move/fire/range info)
Money (play money)
Equipment pieces for 4 countries
4 Flag markers
Generic air & naval base markers and damage markers
2 air-range measures
4 dice

I'm not sure how many of these were produced; mine is an original, mimeographed in a printed folder.

21394.name: Massive Star Corps
21394.description:
Based on the earlier 'Star Corps: Call to Battle'

Updated that game with new movement and combat rules and adds an alternating action system.

Includes:

Pink (black print) cover for the package
12-page rulebook
(5) counter & play aid cards
(10) cards with 4-6 unit status cards on each
(2) blank of the above (for personal mods)


http://www.teamfrog.com/fig-sc.htm

21395.description:
FRAG is a game that portrays the action and quick death of a First Person Shooter computer game on the gaming table. The game quickly grew with two expansions.

Finally there is an expansion to take your FRAG game to the third dimensions. FRAG Miniatures is a box of 6 metal Minis for use with the FRAG game. Included in the box are special rules and variants for using the FRAG minis in your FRAG game.

Each separate mini has their own special rules that change the game.

If you get two boxes you can use them to make two teams ((red and blue for instance)) for playing classic FPS games like Capture the Flag ((CtF)) or Team Death match.

Expands:

Frag
21395.name: Frag Miniatures

21396.name: Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer
21396.description:
In 1948, Parker Brothers indulged in a slight bit of overproduction when it introduced its version of the Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer game. Two to four players compete at this spin-and-move race to the chimney.

There are two editions to this game. One is a standard long-box game with a traditional foldout game board, featuring flat plastic reindeer on wooden stands. The other edition features a 3-D rooftop game board that sits atop the game box, with holes in the roof to insert the plastic reindeer for movement. Both editions include a wooden nose for Rudolph to help a player in moving through the cloud spaces.

The 3-D version also came with a Santa Claus sack of five jingle bells so that players could mark how many times they had won. I do not recall if the standard edition came with this sack.

21397.name: Swamp Fox
21397.description:
You are Colonel Francis Marion (the Swamp Fox). Be the first player to capture three British Soldiers and return to Snow's Island.
Based on the Disney series.

21398.name: Goofy's Mad Maze Game
21398.description: For Ages 7 - 12, be the first to find his way through the maze. In addition to the walls of the maze, there are other hazards to avoid and the ability to jump over walls if the spinner lands on 'jump'

21399.name: Card Games For Two
21399.description:
Book (150 pages) describes and analyzes nine two-player card games:
Piquet
Klaberjass
Demon Patience
Ecarte
Six-pack Bezique
Gin Rummy
Cribbage
Two-handed Bridge
Canasta

21400.name: Shoestring Racer
21400.description:
From the game's introduction

"Shoestring Racer is a game about racing at the bottom end of the financial spectrum, where getting a bike built at all is a triumph of determination over lack of cash. The first part of the game represents the panic-stricken rushing around to get the racing goodies in the last fortnight before the racing season starts and the second part is the actual race, in which you discover whether your hastily assembled pile of bits is a potential winner."

Components
- Board featuring racetrack on one side, buildup grid on the other.
- 8 page rules booklet (A5 size).
- Movement Aid sheet (A4) giving examples of various moves.
- 2 decks of cards/tiles "Shop" and "Practice".
- pad of score sheets.
- plastic bike tokens.

21401.description:
The Runemaster Character Deck introduces new mechanics and rules for character advancement and interaction. Add the abilities of a Runemaster to any character you may choose for Runebound (Second Edition) and expand your powers and abilities, or mix your Runemaster character deck with any of the five others available to produce your own, completely unique hero!

This expansion includes 5 Talent cards, 25 Class cards, and assorted tokens.

Belongs to the Runebound Series.

Expands:

Runebound (Second Edition)
21401.name: Runebound: Runemaster Character Deck

21402.description:
The Battlemage Character Deck introduces new mechanics and rules for character advancement and interaction. Add the abilities of a Battlemage to any character you may choose for Runebound (Second Edition) and expand your powers and abilities, or mix your Battlemage character deck with any of the five others available to produce your own, completely unique hero!

This expansion includes 5 Talent cards, 25 Class cards, and assorted tokens.

Belongs to the Runebound Series.

Expands:

Runebound (Second Edition)
21402.name: Runebound: Battlemage Character Deck

21403.name: Eugene en Italie
21403.description:
Eugene en Italie (Eugene in Italy) is a DTP game, portraying the 1809 campaign of Prince Eugene (Napoleon's stepson) in Venetia.
Units are brigades for infantry and regiments for cavalry. Three scenarios are provided, one on the battle of Sacile (15 turns), one of 9 turns on the clash on the banks of the Piave river, and a full campaign scenario of 45 turns.

21404.name: Backyard Bug Buffet
21404.description:
Backyard Bug Buffet: Play this fun and easy game in which your insect species races to increase its population to the victory level, before the other players' species do!

Search the board for your required food, eat it or collect it, and breed young. Watch out for the predators out there though! They won't hesitate to gobble your six-legged animals!

Backyard Bug Buffet is a good introduction to the study and appreciation of insects, for children ages 6 and up.

Components:
1 washable felt mapboard
135 colored chips
40 plastic insects
56 food & predator tiles
6 species information cards
2 bonus predator information cards
rules
die

Game Ratings: non-aggressive, moderately competitive
Skill-Luck Ratio: 2:3

21405.description:
The Shadow Walker Character Deck introduces new mechanics and rules for character advancement and interaction. Add the abilities of a Shadow Walker to any character you may choose for Runebound (Second Edition) and expand your powers and abilities, or mix your Shadow Walker character deck with any of the five others available to produce your own, completely unique hero!

This expansion includes 5 Talent cards, 25 Class cards, and assorted tokens.

Belongs to the Runebound Series.

Expands:

Runebound (Second Edition)
21405.name: Runebound: Shadow Walker Character Deck

21406.description:
The Blade Dancer Character Deck introduces new mechanics and rules for character advancement and interaction. Add the abilities of a Blade Dancer to any character you may choose for Runebound (Second Edition) and expand your powers and abilities, or mix your Blade Dancer character deck with any of the five others available to produce your own, completely unique hero!

This expansion includes 5 Talent cards, 25 Class cards, and assorted tokens.

Belongs to the Runebound Series.

Expands:

Runebound (Second Edition)
21406.name: Runebound: Blade Dancer Character Deck

21407.description: The one (and only) expansion for Baston, featuring street map boards, new cardboard figures, new weapons (nunchakus and trash can lids), a phone booth and 6 new scenarios.
21407.name: Baston: La Rue – extension n° 1

21408.name: Damals & Heute: Selecta Nobile
21408.description:
[Translated roughly from web pages]

A version of the the memory game for older participants than the classic game. Players try to find matches of tiles that have an association between two objects. One of the tiles is from a historical perspective and one from contemporary times. The play is meant to invoke discussions about the associations and provide a learning experience for those involved.

21409.name: Eyewitness News Game
21409.description:
A Buffalo, NY Game. Made to commemorate an award winning news team for channel 7 WKBW-TV. On Front of Box:

Your chance to become a junior reporter for Eyewitness News! Be the first back to the station with all the facts and get your story on the air.

WKBW-TV Net proceeds donated to the Buffalo Variety club for Children's Hospital.

(This uses a one sided board, which is a redo of the Blizzard of '77 Travel game)

21410.name: Sliders
21410.description: Based on curling, players move their two Sliders across the table or another smooth surface. Score 1 point for being closest to the edge, 2 points for a 'cliffhanger'. First player to score 10 points wins. Variant: use a target instead of the edge of the table.

21411.description:
Island War is a "Quadrigame" containing four separate battles:


Bloody Ridge - Guadalcanal, Sept 1942 (designed by Kevin Zucker)
Saipan - June 1944 (Kip Allen)
Leyte - October 1944 (Jay Nelson)
Okinawa - April 1945 (Larry Pinsky).


Each game is played on its own map. Counter density is fairly low and each map is folio sized. Includes Standard rules common to all four games and exclusive rules for each individual game. 400 counters
21411.name: Island War: Four Pacific Battles

21412.description: Just how well do you know your fellow players? Read a card with two words that describe another player. Serious or silly? Blizzard or hurricane? Can you guess which word is most like him? If so, you both score points! Play with those you think you know and those you'd like to know better.
21412.name: Take Your Pick

21413.description: Four games in one, this is no ordinary chess set. Take Chess to a whole new level! Add a new challenge to your game by adding the Frankencheck monster to the board in Frankencheck. Dig for treasures and uncover special points in Treasure Chessed. Or win UFO Spell Check by collecting letters, spell words, and add bonus words to the board. You may never want to play chess the same again!
21413.name: Chess on the Loose

boardgamehonor.8422: 2009 Golden Geek Best Print & Play Board Game Nominee

21414.description:
To The Last Man! is a strategic level wargame of World War 1 covering all aspects of the western front.

To The Last Man! uses cards to allow units to fight, take replacements and affect the course of the game with key technological, military, and political events. Players alternate playing cards and moving pieces. The game sequence is very interactive, with NO down time waiting for the other player to take his turn. The combat system has both players rolling dice in each combat.

In this two-player game each player starts the campaign game and 1914 scenario with cards that also represent the prewar stocks of ammunition, reserves and planning that allows the war to start off with a large bang. After players expend this allotment of cards, they must purchase more cards along with new units. Each player's resources are limited, so players often will not be able to launch large offensives every turn. They'll need to husband their resources. This represents the preparation for the next "Big Push." All of this leads to difficult game decisions all the way through the game.

There are scenarios for each year of the war from 1914 to 1918, along with the hypothetical Fuller or 1919 offensive. Also included are the many war plans conceived prior to the war and their appropriate set-ups so you could, for example, try the French 1909 plan vs. the German Schlieffen Plan.

Rules include: Great Offensives, Stosstruppen, tanks, gas attacks, cavalry, huge dogfights, reserves, siege guns, forts, events on other fronts, and much more.
21414.name: To The Last Man!

21415.description:
Blockade is a game designed for a standard piecepack.

The runner (using the 4 pawns) attempts to move any one pawn from one end of the board to the other.

The blocker (using the 24 coins) tries to prevent the runner from succeeding, by trapping the runner, causing the runner to have no remaining possible moves.

Online Play


Super Duper Games
21415.name: Blockade

21416.description:
This is a very small, very inexpensive ($1.79) wargame covering the whole of the Thirty Years War. The three players represent Austria, Sweden, and the Palatinate. Production, political influence, and status are all kept on a small record sheet. The map and counters are made of paper. Victory is determined by victory points based on captured cities and aggregate political influence.

Obviously published on a shoestring, there's enough meaty game play here to have warranted a more substantial treatment.
21416.name: The Thirty Years War

21417.description:
The Desert Hive Pack is a supplement to the Insecta game Mutant Kit edition. It consists of the original 2nd edition Hive deck, which when combined with the Mutant Kit is equivalent to the full 2nd edition package minus the color cover and rubber bugs. This enables play of the Hive Game, pitting a player team against 70+ desert-adapted bugs in a five-level fight for survival.

Expands:

Insecta (Mutant Kit edition)
21417.name: Insecta: Desert Hive

21418.name: The Margaret & David At The Movies Boardgame
21418.description:
From the back of the box:

The Margaret & David At The Movies Boardgame takes the world's most popular pastime - watching movies - and turns it into a trivia battle supreme!

Inside this box you'll find 3600 questions about everything from Alien to Zoolander - with a few classics thrown into the mix.

You don't need to be a film buff to win. The clever gameplay means that everyone is kept in the picture and no-one ends up on the cutting room floor.

In fact, if your expertise only stretches to Dumb & Dumber you could still beat a player who has a PhD in the films of Martin Scorsese.

The game is a box-office smash that simply demands encore after encore!

21419.description:
This expansion kit for the award-winning Sword of Rome game adds Carthage as a player power and requires ownership of Sword of Rome.

Carthage now has their own customized deck of 38 strategy cards plus there are 8 new events that replace cards in the Etruscan, Roman, and Greek decks. Additionally, Carthage has special powers that emphasize its historic strengths.


Carthage can hire mercenaries allowing lesser peoples to do the dirty job of fighting for them.



Carthage is the pre-eminent naval power of the era and has the ability to interdict any naval movement, blockade enemy cities, and provide supplies to allied cities under siege.



Carthage can also provide the use of its ships to allies, allowing them to move great distances to launch unexpected attacks.


Perhaps Carthage will ally with the Greeks and sweep north using their combined navies to turn the tide, but what of Sicily? It now provides reinforcements and VPs for conquering it for both the Greeks and Carthage, but at a severe cost to the side that is denied the island. Perhaps the Greek player has allied with you just to encourage you to sail to Rome so he can launch a Sicilian campaign. And what of failure? The Carthaginian general who has the audacity to lose a battle may be crucified for his incompetence. The generals who survive always keep in mind that their mercenaries' loyalty lie not with Carthage, but with silver and gold.

Expands:

Sword of Rome
21419.name: Sword of Rome 5th Player Expansion

21420.name: Monopoly: Centennial Olympic Games
21420.description:
The Official 1996 Olympic Games Edition.

This one was sold at the souvenir booth at the Atlanta Olympic games. On the bottom of the box are printed the Games pictograms of the major sports and there is a numbered holographic "Authentic" sticker on the box bottom, upper right hand corner.

The game remains the same, however the spaces depict the posters of the Olympic games and their host cities over the years:

Purple: St. Louis 1904, London 1908
Lt. Blue: Stockholm 1912, Belgium 1920, Paris 1924
Maroon: Amsterdam 1928, Los Angeles 1932, Berlin 1936
Orange: London 1948, Helsinki 1952, Melbourne 1956
Red: Rome 1960, Tokyo 1964, Mexico 1968
Yellow: Munich 1972, Montreal 1976, Moscow 1980
Green: Los Angeles 1984, Seoul 1988, Barcelona 1992
Blue: Athens 1896, Atlanta 1996

21421.description:
The Wildlander character deck introduces new mechanics and rules for character advancement and interaction. Add the abilities of a Wildlander to any character you may choose for Runebound (Second Edition) and expand your powers and abilities, or mix your Wildlander character deck with any of the five others available to produce your own, completely unique hero!

This expansion includes 5 Talent cards, 25 Class cards, and assorted tokens.

Belongs to the Runebound Series.

Expands:

Runebound (Second Edition)
21421.name: Runebound: Wildlander Character Deck

21422.description:
The Spiritbound character deck introduces new mechanics and rules for character advancement and interaction. Add the abilities of a Spiritbound to any character you may choose for Runebound (Second Edition) and expand your powers and abilities, or mix your Spiritbound character deck with any of the five others available to produce your own, completely unique hero!

This expansion includes 5 Talent cards, 25 Class cards, and assorted tokens.

Belongs to the Runebound Series.

Expands:

Runebound (Second Edition)
21422.name: Runebound: Spiritbound Character Deck

21423.description: This is a game about the war in AOI during the World War II (1940-41)
21423.name: A.O.I. (Africa Oriental Italiana)

21424.name: Tilt
21424.description:
Tilt is yet another marble race game. The object of the game is to be the first player to move all four of his marbles around the board and into the center "home" area. The twist is that the board see-saws up and down depending on the position of the marbles. At the start, the board is perfectly balanced, but as the players move the marbles, the board tilts back and forth depending on the weight distribution of the marbles.

There are 18 "slide" areas around the board, and should your marble end up in one of these slides, a tilt of the board may send your marble forward or backward, or possibly right into the "home" area." (Think "Chutes and Ladders" with actual chutes.)

Though essentially a children's roll-and-move game, young players will quickly learn how to make the laws of gravity work for them. There is also some low-level strategy as players may choose to move their marbles backward if it would allow them to enter a slide.

21425.name: Pick A Pair!
21425.description:
Book of thirty new two player games:
Co-ords
Tetral
Trios
Man-trap
Towers
Guess Race
Harlequin
Owteno
Maze
Serpents
Tripod
Countdown
Squeeze
Pathway
Mosaic
Crocogator
Steeplechase
Leapfrog
Necklace
Tug o'war
Walkover
Rhombic
Spiders
Summit
Star Shoot
Cross-fire
Nemesis
Triads
Roundabouts
Tandems

21426.description: Players compete to occupy the most valuable gold claims. This game was included in the July-September 2005 edition of Spielbox and requires colored stones or tokens and a deck of playing cards to play. Each turn, players have a number of points to move their stones along the track towards the gold claim spaces.
21426.name: Snake River Claims

21427.name: Conquest: The Medieval Strategy Game
21427.description:
"The playing board is divided into four kingdoms (colored separately), each controlled by a different player. The object of the game is to conquer all the other kingdoms on the board and bring them under your rule."

1 Playing Board
4 Big Pegs
1 Die
50 Brown Foot Soldier Chips
30 Blue Horse Chips
20 Red Chariot Chips
20 Green Worker Chips
50 Big Yellow Chips (i.e. gold coins) with printed stickers of 5, 10 and 50
20 Calamity Cards

21428.name: Royal Carpet
21428.description:
An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

Object: Be the first player to get two Kings off the far edge of the board. This is done by laying down a carpet of friendly Checkers for the Kings to jump.

Only one piece may be moved or introduced per turn. Checkers may be introduced onto any empty square. Alternatively, Checkers may move to any adjacent, empty square. A King may only move by jumping (in any direction) over friendly Checkers or Kings, capturing as he goes. Captured Checkers may be reintroduced later, but Kings that are captured do not return to the game.

The mechanics of jumping are the same as in the game Checkers, except that Kings may jump off the far edge of the board, into the 'end zone.' This King is removed from play. If a King has an opportunity to jump, he must jump, continuing until no more jumps are possible. So beware!

Winning: Victory is achieved when a player has jumped two Kings into the end zone.

Royal Carpet is an attempt to create a game of tempo in which friendly pieces have both positive and negative synergies. Crafty players will block jumps and then unblock them later, forcing an enemy King to jump his royal brethren. For those so inclined, this game is fun to play with a backgammon doubling cube, held initially by the Red player.

21430.name: Sibling Rivalry
21430.description:
An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

The sibling rivalry between you and your brother is legendary. Some ascribe the antagonism to the circumstances of your birth: When the Queen bore identical twins sons many years ago, a careless midwife placed both infants in the same bassinet without identifying the elder, and the rightful heir to the throne has been in doubt ever since. Others believe that your fierce competitiveness is simply a distillation of the belligerence that runs throughout your bloodline. For whatever reason, you have spent your entire life trying to prove your superiority to your brother.

Unfortunately, that life is about to end.

Four days ago Barbarians attacked from the west. Both you and your brother marshaled your individual forces and followed your father to meet the enemy. At first it seemed the battle would be easily won: for each of your soldiers who fell in battle a score of Marauders were dispatched. But by the third day it became apparent that, while your own forces rapidly dwindled, there would be no end to the Barbarian horde. And this morning your losing battle quickly became a rout: The King was slain, you found yourself surrounded, and the forces controlled by you and your brother were reduced to a mere handful a piece.

Now, as the Marauders press in, you know that you will soon be sent to your reward. But you don't fear death. In fact, only one thing weighs on your mind: this is your absolute last chance to outdo your brother. And you are certain he is thinking the same thing.

Object: Each player will attempt to amass more Kills than his opponent before both Princes die in battle.

Reference cards are also provided but not required.

21431.name: F1 (Formula-1)
21431.description: Formula-1 auto racing game published in Russian. Half-page of 'English' rules translated by a non-native English speaker. Appears to be just a roll and move game with a little strategy in choosing which of two lanes to select when moving forward or diagonally following connecting arrows. Track is in color on heavy paper approximately 17 x 22 inches and, from the graphics, appears to be a track in Australia. Cars on heavy paper are approximately 1 inch cutouts that are folded into a triangular 'tube' to give a 3D representation.

21432.description:
Description quoted from the rulebook:
"The object of the game is to achieve the highest total score including bonuses. This is accomplished by rolling dice combinations which match the categories on the score sheet and by the skillful choice of scoring options."

Imagine playing Yahtzee with poker dice, and you've got the basic premise of Royal Kismet. There are three suits available - red, black, and green - with values from 6 to Ace in each suit. Players attempt to create a poker hand (or other scoring set) after rolling the dice three times.

What makes Royal Kismet truly unique are the dice included. Each die has a unique distribution of numbers and suits - making it much tougher to calculate the odds of rolling that last Ace you need. (Blank sides and a Joker can also affect the roll.)
21432.name: Royal Kismet

21433.description:
A game to help very young children (Ages 4 - 6) learn to count. Game develops counting and pattern recognition skills.

Each player takes on the role of a seal catching fish.

Role a die (value 1-3) and move around a track on the edge of the board (with a wooden seal figure) which depicts patterns found on fish in the middle of the board. After moving, a player must find/identify all the fish in the middle of the board with the pattern corresponding to the space on the track they have landed on. The players then collect a number of small wooden fish equal to the number of fish they have found. When all the wooden fish are collected the game ends and the player with the most fish wins.

The game also includes rules and extra equipment for a slightly more involved game (requiring just a touch more counting skills).

From the box:
"The little sea lions frolic about at the pool edge. They hunt, catch, count and share many little fish. The colorful game board converts counting into an exciting search game.

A game for 2-4 little sea lions ages 4 and up. Two simple game ideas for an exciting first approach to the numbers 1-10."
21433.name: Eins, Vier, Viele

21434.name: Final Strategy
21434.description:
"Final Strategy is an exciting, fast paced board game which challenges your ability to use offensive and defensive strategy. Armed with Troops, Captors and Bombs, you use your wits to dominate territory and capture opponents' Troops."

Printed in Canada. The only obvious connection to WWI is in the line-drawing graphics on the box. Box is identical in size to Mystery on the Nile.

110 Troops (36 maroon, 36 tan, 22 green, 16 blue) - Plastic cylinders
180 Barriers - White plastic T-shapes
4 Bunkers - Thick paperboard triangles meant to be folded to make screens
4 Bombs - White plastic 'mushrooms'
12 Captors - Blue plastic 'golf tees'

21435.name: Shoot The Moon
21435.description:
This is a trick-taking card game, which may be played individually or in partnerships of 2 or 3.

The game comes with a deck of 52 cards, made up of 4 colored sets of 12 cards (numbered 1 to 12) - the colored sets are suits of red rockets (always trump), green crescent moons, purple stars and blue full moons. There are also 2 orange big moon (bonus cards, always high), 2 orange little moon cards (penalty cards, always low) and 40 Shoot the Moon chips.

Players start with 2 chips and are dealt 5 cards for each round of play. Players gain chips by winning odd number of tricks or the big moon cards. The first player to win 7 chips wins.

This is not the same game as the other game with this title in the BGG database - that one appears to be a set-collecting card game.

21436.description:
18FL -- Railroads to Paradise

Designer's intro from manual:
18FL is an 18xx game set in Florida. 18FL is a small 18xx game, in the style of Mark Derrick’s “one-state”
games 18GA and 18AL, and is intended as a change from the more robust 18xx games often played.

It is my hope that it may serve effectively as a “teaching game” as well, allowing new players a relatively benign introduction to the 18xx family of games.
21436.name: 18FL

21437.name: Agora Barcelona
21437.description:
Overview:
Ever since Barcelona was founded its citizens, of whatever class or condition, have taken advantage of their moments of leisure to stroll around the city's squares, always finding time to visit their local neighborhood plaça or some other square a little further away. Whether imposing or intimate, latest-generation or laden with legends, verdantly planted or starkly concrete, the squares of Barcelona are genuine spaces of communication and enjoyment.

Agora Barcelona is a majority game played on the street map of Barcelona, as the players try to occupy more and more squares with their strollers.

21438.name: Un Po d'acqua a Torino
21438.description:
One of few limited "Single card games" made from GiocaTorino for the first "Ludo Day" done the 18th of December 2005.

Very few copies of this game were made. The game itself was printed on regular paper and was a gift for people who were participating in the Ludo Day.

21439.name: Después de Colditz
21439.description:
"Después de Colditz" (After Colditz) is the sequel to the acclaimed game "Fuga de Colditz" (Escape from Colditz), designed by Major P. R. Reid, B. Degas and the production team at NAC.

The escape from the castle was only the beginning of a long adventure that would take the prisoners along several escape routes out of Germany. The most important routes were Switzerland, Spain, the Baltic (on to Sweden) and Bretagne (on to Great Britain).

Along the escape routes the players will encounter many obstacles such as the German army, the Gestapo, German civilians, etc. Intelligence, stamina, the knowledge of foreign languages, luck and audacity are all represented in the game.

One of the players will lead the German security forces and the rest will play as teams of escapees.

21440.name: Fazendo Novela
21440.description: Fazendo Novela (Making Soap Operas) is a game created and used by Globo Network in their workshop for new authors. Players use cards to create characters, plots, scenes and, even, commercials. By the end players vote the winners.

boardgamehonor.8854: 2006 Golden Geek Best Gamer's Board Game Nominee

21441.description:
1899. For more than a century, the European public has been fascinated by Egyptology and the discoveries of Denon, Champollion, Petrie and others. Seeking adventure and glory, teams of archaeologists search the sands of Egypt for hidden treasures.

Mykerinos. Embody archaeologists seeking relics from ancient Egypt for powerful benefactors. Will you be convincing at the museum's final exhibition?

The game takes place over four rounds. The game board is composed of four (or six in the last round) areas of two cards. These cards have 6 squares, possibly occupied by an obstacle (pyramid), and belonging to one of five benefactors (with their own color and symbol): Sir Brown, Lady Violet, Miss Blackmore, Lord Lemon and Colonel Tangerine.

Each player has their own personal pool of archaeologists that can be used to:
- Start an excavation (requiring one archaeologist)
- Expand an excavation (requiring two archaeologists in addition to one archaeologist already on the board)
- Play a benefactor previously earned
- Pass

Benefactors give special benefits like moving over an obstacle or retrieving archaeologists faster, etc ...

Once all players have passed, we resolve the board according to area control. The player in the first position can either take a card available or go to the museum. Other players can then do the same. Ties are resolved according to player order.

Going to the Museum adds value for a colour at endgame to the cards collected (x2, x3 or x5).

At the end of the 4th round, the final exhibition is resolved and the winning player will be whoever collected the most prestige between:
- Points on the cards collected during game
- Points by colour benefactors (according to position in the museum)
- Bonus points for sets of cards (1 in every colour of benefactors).
21441.name: Mykerinos

21442.name: Do You Sudoku? Game
21442.description:
From the box:
Now Sudoku can be played in teams. Players race to see who can complete their Sudoku puzzle first.

More than 100 different puzzles designed at three different levels. Teams can choose their level or roll the dice and meet the challenge.

21443.description:
"De Specialisten van Catan" (Catan's Specialists) is a separately sold expansion for The Settlers of Catan. It also needs Catan: Seafarers.

Players build their villages on small islands with only a limit number of resources available. None of the starting islands provide sheep. The specialist trade ports gain importance. Additionally players can become specialist in one or more of the resources gaining additional victory points and free resource cards each turn.
21443.name: De Kolonisten van Catan: De Specialisten

21444.name: The Fitness Challenge
21444.description:
From the back of the box

It's the game that can help you lose weight!
Pick a Partner...and engage in a friendly competition.

The Fitness Challenge rallies you and your partner (spouse, relative, friend, co-worker) to exercise for eight weeks. It doesn't matter if you are just starting out or if you have been exercising for some time, The Fitness Challenge allows you to play no matter what shape you're in.

Game rules are designed to motivate you to exercise at least three days a week, every week, for eight weeks. From walking to mountain climbing, the range of workout choices accommodates any lifestyle.

With The Fitness Challenge Scorecard, you and your workout buddy get a fun and simple way to track your progress as you progress on your track. Pick from a selection of zany coupons to make up a Wager Book. The Wager Book is your incentive to stay on track... and your opportunity to stick it to your partner if they don't hold up their end of the bargain!

21445.name: Spider and Fly
21445.description:
The square gameboard resting inside the box lid represents a spider's web. The little wooden tops that players spin are the spiders. The numbered holes on the gameboard represent flies the spiders want to capture and eat.

from the box lid:

Each player, in turn, takes the two wooden spinners and spins them one at a time in the center of the "web". For each top which rests in a numbered compartment with the sphere end down, the player scores the amount printed under it. If the spinner rests in a compartment with the peg end down, the player scores double. A game consists of 100 points, and the first player who scores that amount is the winner.

21446.name: Tournée Générale
21446.description:
The most refreshing game you've ever tasted
Tournée Générale is a quiz game about Belgian beers.

21447.name: Brother against Brother
21447.description:
Miniature wargame.
American Civil War small action rules. Including optional rules for the French & Indian war, and other periods.

"Brother Against Brother" is a rule set for small actions and skirmishes between company or smaller, sized units. In order to allow for a wargame to be completed in a short length of time - about 3-4 hours - the rules are as simple and short as possible, but maintain the feel of firefight from the American Civil War period.

Equipment needed:
1 or more tape measures in inches.
3 or more D10 dice.
Cotton balls.
Appropriate figures (about ten figures/squad).
Scenery for the table (the more the better).

21448.name: COO-COO

4945.name: Herbert Specialty Mfg. Co. of Chicago

21448.description:
COO-COO is a party game published in 1921. Players punch out a hole in the pegboard using a metal "key." A little wad of paper is pushed out, which when unrolled reveals a slip containing some stunt the player must perform. Each pegboard contains 100 stunts.

from the box:

Every COO-COO game contains 100 different stunts. COO-COO is issued in series; every series is entirely different from every other series. The numbers are shown on the end of the boxes.

DIRECTIONS FOR PLAYING

are shown on the front of the game board.

A good variation is to have the player do the stunt called for on his slip, while the others attempt to guess what he is doing.

Sometimes the hostess will select one of her men guests to start the game. When he has done his stunt, he gives the board to any lady he chooses for the next stunt. After playing she hands the board to a man, etc., till all have played.

COO-COO will be even more successful if the hostess announces before the play starts that a prize will be awarded to the lady and another to the man doing his stunt the best.

The judges may declare a tie and require two more stunts played by e»ch of those tied, thus prolonging the fun.

21450.name: Alien Galaxy
21450.description:
Guided by the voice of Mission Control, Squadron Commanders must avoid deadly Laser fire, pierce Meteor storms, defense missile systems and many other perils of the Alien Galaxy....Surround yourselves with the sound of Intergalactic Adventure as the play the cassette tape included with the game....

The object of the game is to maneuver your spacecraft avoiding the hazards, black holes etc ..The winner is the last player with any of their spacecraft surviving..

21451.name: Mini Double Dice
21451.description:
A Yahtzee like game where there are 5 hollow, transparent, six-sided dice. Within each is another smaller die. You get three rolls and get to keep any number of dice on each roll, just like Yahtzee. You then score based on 13 categories. Categories are Ones, Twos, Threes, Fours, Fives, Sixes, Odds, Evens, Lo In/Hi Out, Hi In/Lo Out, Lucky 7-11, One Away, Double Dice.

An example of scoring is Lo In/Hi Out: After the third roll, total all the Double Dice (both inner and outer) that have a lower number on the inner die and a higher number on the outer die. If all 5 Double Dice are Lo In/Hi Out, total all dice and DOUBLE the score!

21452.name: Waddington's Cricket Game
21452.description:
From the box:

"Waddington's Cricket Game with batting and bowling. An activity game of real skill and excitement."

Players can either bat or bowl. Although only two players can participate others can act as onlookers or wait their turn to bat and bowl in teams.

Waddington's Cricket Game recreates a cricket pitch on your table or floor. There is a plastic ramp for the bowler to use to deliver small ball-bearings. Another plastic mechanism holds a bat in tension with an elastic band. The batsman releases a trigger to strike at the ball. Scoring depends on how far the ball ends up from the nearest fielder. Fielders are press out cardboard figures that fold into a 3D shape.

21453.name: Alibi
21453.description:
The game consists of 51 cards divided into 4 sets of 12 - Crime, Prosecution, Defense, and Alibi. There are three additional cards - the Prisoner and 2 Surprise Witness cards.

The game is essentially a trick-taking game with 3 of the sets. The Alibi set is not shuffled in, but acts as a scoring mechanism as players receive these cards for winning tricks. Witness cards act as trump cards.

21454.name: Crow Hunt
21454.description:
This 1931 game from Parker Brothers was advertised as a splendid shooting game. Crows were inserted on a slide at the rear of a target and automatically appear one at a time. Using a repeating rifle which shot 6 elastic bands, the object was to hit the birds who slid down the ramp and into an opening in the background target. When you hit one the next one slid down into place. Each bird that you hit was worth 1 point. The last bird hit was a duck named "Elmer" He was worth 5 points if you successfully hit him. First person to get 25 points won the game.

the ad for the game stated that additional ammunition (60 elastic bands) were available for 30 cents from Parker Brothers.

21455.description:
This game is for young people. It was designed to teach them their A, B, C's. The object of the game was simple. The first person to move his piece from a to y and z wins the game.
Color determines the move. Each player selects a piece to move (Panda, Kitty, etc. The a player spins the arrow and depending on which color shows up he/she moves to the corresponding colored letter. Other players spin and then place their piece on the first unoccupied letter with the color that they spun. First person to get to y or z (both winning letters) wins the game.
21455.name: Teddy Bear Panda and His Friends

21456.name: Tom Swift
21456.description:
The object of this game is to have the highest score at the end of the game. The game comes with 5 playing pieces, 5 travel cards, 16 plan cards, a score card, dice, one marble, Tom Swift cards, a playing board and a Polar Ray Gun.
Players try to make a complete tour around each of the four travel areas of the board in an effort to get a plan from each of those areas.

There is also a ray gun in this game. It is used to shoot a marble into a area with holes valued with differing points.

Once a player has gone through all sections and has a plan from Space, Air, Land and Undersea and returns his travel card his turns ends. On the next turn he puts the pieces of the plan together, takes a shot with his ray gun either for more score or to end the game.

21457.description:
A great two-player strategy game!
Cover Up takes seconds to learn and minutes to play. Cover your opponent’s options,while uncovering your plan to win. Four in a row wins the game! Reach new levels with Cover Up!

Each player has five little pieces, four medium pieces and three big pieces. Once placed, the small and medium pieces may not be moved. However the large piece can be moved.
21457.name: Cover Up

21458.name: Hole in One: the Game
21458.description:
A trivia roll and move board game......Object of the game: acquire the trivia tees(par,birdie and eagle) and have the lowest scoring round of golf.
Trivia tees categories:
Eagle: extremely difficult for pro players
Birdie:golf courses..rules,golf records etc..
Par: golf basics etc

21459.name: Trivial Pursuit Music Master Game: The '60s Edition
21459.description: Stock question card combines with 99 track CD and answer booklet. Some of the songs are British hits instead of American, but many of them are worldwide hits.

21461.name: Big Mouth
21461.description:
Big Mouth comes in quite a large box (15" x 16" x 3.5").

Each player is given a large 14" red plastic fork and a paper plate on which there are 6 different plastic food items and a green bug. A thin piece of cardboard is placed over a plastic bowl. The cardboard is designed in the shape of a cute clown with a hole forming the entrance to his oral cavity, which is formed by the bowl.

A spinner directs gameplay. There are 7 equal segments on the spinner, representing each food object & the green bug.

If a food object is spun, players race to be the first to feed it to the clown with their fork. Losers replace their food object on their plate. If a player has already successfully fed that particular food object to the clown on a previous turn they instead try to feed the clown the green bug. If successful, opponents cannot feed the clown the food object that was spun on that turn and the bug is retrieved from the mouth of the clown & returned to its position.

If the green bug is spun, ANY food object may be placed in the clown's mouth.

The first player to feed all the food on their plate into the mouth of the clown is the winner.

21463.name: John Silver
21463.description:
Description of the game from Spielbox:

John Silver', a card game by Martin Schlegel. John Silver is an "ah, I see" game - you play out a card and wonder who's going to take the trick. And when the trick is taken, it's usually accompanied by "ah, I see".

When a row of 4 cards is complete the two tricks will be distributed amongst the winners:
The highest card "grabs" the second-highest card, and the lowest card "grabs" the second-lowest card.
The value of this tricks does not depend on their number but on the coins (good points) or broken treasure maps (negative points) printed onto the playing cards. Additionally there are apples on some cards that offer points to the player sitting to the left from you.

21464.description:
From the back of the box:

Who doesn't dream of owning a large Mansion in the sun-drenched hills of California? But before you can furnish the house according to your wishes the interior must be renovated. Just as you have completed furnishing the first rooms you curious neighbors begin to drop by, some bearing housewarming gifts. A good thing too ... because victory will go to the one with the most beautifully renovated house and the largest collection of gifts.

Description of the game from The Goblins' Lair:

Players have inherited a small amount of money and a house on the sunny hills of California. Unluckily the house is in a very bad condition. It will be to the players make it habitable again: renewing the rooms with the most exclusive furniture. Better and more friendly will be the house, more neighbors will come bringing presents and friendship.

During the game the players could take money from the bank or buy tiles from the shops to place in the house. Before furnishing a room and welcoming people they have to renovate the room. Bonus cards could be gained being the first to furnish the rooms with particular combination of objects. It will be always possible to get loans ...

At the end of the game (the 12th day) every player will score points for every present, every bonus card and every renovated room in their house. After paying debts the player with the most victory points will be the winner.
21464.name: California

21465.name: Crazy Diamond & Karatino
21465.description:
Description from the designer:

Crazy Diamond & Karatino are two games on a unique double-sided playing board. In Crazy Diamond, the players try to smuggle as many diamonds as possible across the board. But the trip is risky! The players travel along the various routes using planes, jeeps and speedboats. They can bribe the local police in order to get control of important ports and airports. The first player who owns 25 diamonds wins the game.

In Karantino, each player is faced with the challenge of processing the rough diamonds and selling them at the right moment. However, there is a limited amount of storage space and there are other players on the market, looking to get the better of you! The combination of luck, strategy and interaction makes Karantino a unique and very addictive game.

21466.name: Monkeys!
21466.description: Monkeys! Who knew it could be so tough to keep a banana? Scare the monkey away from your precious bananas or send monkeys after your opponents. Oh, and try to stop laughing before time runs out. Join your friends in a frenzy of fast-paced silliness!

21467.name: Happy Landing
21467.description:
Each player is given four wooden chips (or airplanes) of a color and one wooden shooter (or propeller). 'Airplanes' are placed onto the 'propeller' and are catapulted onto the gameboard by tapping the far side of the 'propeller'.

The board consists of a box insert depicting various features surrounding a landing strip, each labeled with either positive or negative points. In the center of the board is a cup, which is the highest scoring feature and true target.

Excerpted from the box:

The game is based on the principle of an airplane trying to land safely without "cracking up." This is called a Happy Landing.

21468.name: Shmo
21468.description:
"I'm a Shmo and that ain't good."

Each player is provided a "Shmo" marker (a plastic boy in short pants) which is placed onto an oversized board. Players roll the dice and move along a path containing such features as "Forgets his trousers...", "Takes wrong school bus..." or "Walks through wet cement." Each special feature directs the player to advance a number of spaces and pick a "Shmo card". The cards direct the player to perform some silly act and declare himself a shmo (Scratch your back 10 times and say, "I'm an itchy shmo!").

At the end of the path is a large box declaring: "First one here is a SHMO... ...and that ain't good!"

Shmo is a Tumblebum dice game, which is to say that the two dice are placed into an hourglass-shaped device (Tumblebum) which is spun around in order to roll the dice.

21469.name: Spectral Rails
21469.description:
For years prospectors, speculators, and frontier folk flocked to remote areas of the American Southwest in search of their fortunes. Makeshift towns cropped up around rich mines of copper, silver, gold and other precious commodities, only to fade away as the resources ran out. Now only ghost towns are left as testament to the community that once lived there. While the lucky ones made their fortunes; most folks barely scratched out a meager existence in these harsh and lonely towns. Some died lonely deaths in these places far from home, and now their souls wander around these ghost towns haunting them until the day when their soul can return home to achieve final peace. The ghost trains are these lost souls’ ticket to rest. These spectral trains glide majestically along ethereal rails looking for lost souls and give them passage homeward. You are the engineer of a ghost train. Your job is to find lost souls in various ghost towns and deliver them to their home towns so that they can achieve final peace

Players are Engineers of Ghost Trains traveling through the American Southwest. Each player uses their standard set of Ether cards (1-4) to move, picking up souls and delivering them to Ghost Towns. As you move, you expend Ether to lay track behind. Other players can move along on your Ether track for free, but you may never travel along your own Ether.

As you lay down more track, your old Ether disperses -- you can pull up your track to clear the way for yourself or to leave someone in the lurch.

A portion of the game revolves around managing your discard pile, as you only get half of your ether cards back each turn. But most of the game comes down to proper planning along with timing your movement to take advantage of what other people have left you, while trying to disallow easy passage for others.

boardgamehonor.12806: 2008 Boardgames Australia Awards Best Australian Game Nominee

21470.name: SuDoKu: Battle Lines
21470.description:
SuDoKu - Battle Lines is a strategy game where players battle for territory on the game board using color coded, numbered tiles.

Based on the very popular Sudoku number puzzle (where each 3x3 grid, each row and each column must contain all the numbers 1 to 9), this game adds the extra dimension of player combative interaction. For those who enjoy solitaire games, a number of Sudoku puzzles are included - ranging from easy to extremely hard.

21471.description:
This 18-card expansion alters the play of the basic game by giving players cards used to bend the rules in various ways.

It also addresses the disadvantage that later players have in larger games by giving them greater choice of cards.

Contents:

18 Special Cards (2 each of 9 different cards)
1 vinyl zipper (ziplock) bag
1 instruction sheet (in English and Korean)

The cards are still in die-cut sheets, and have to be punched out by hand.

The expansion seems to be included with most games purchased from vendors in the United States; it isn't clear if that applies elsewhere in the world.
21471.name: Gemblo Expansion Set

21472.name: Diversion
21472.description:
This fairly ancient Racing Game (my copy seems at least 50 years old) has no dice whatever, an unusual feature for the genre. The gameboard has a series of turntables on it, which can be rotated so as to alter the paths in front of the players: the skillful manipulation of the turntables lies at the heart of the game. Each turn the player's piece (a small racing car) moves 1,2,3, or 4 squares forwards, at the player's discretion. If he lands on a space with black dots, he can rotate a turntable anywhere on the board, either to clear his path to the finish line or to hinder someone else. The Finish squares when reached give you points, and then you return to the start, only winning when you have 100 pts. It is possible to become completely trapped in an area with no black dots, and this carries a penalty of 20 pts and return to start.
The theme is pasted on, but the deduction and 'screwage factor' involved should appeal to many.

21473.name: Twenty One
21473.description:
Based on the original (1956-58) scandal-riddled game show, one player acts as Quiz Master for two players or teams and chooses a random category for the round. In turn, each secretly chooses a question by number. There are eleven questions, numbered 1-11, and are of graduated difficulty with 11 being the hardest. A right answer adds that amount to their score, a wrong answer takes it away (but scores cannot go below zero).

Neither team knows the other's score, and either may stop the game at any time. The game ends when either 1) a team asks to stop the game or 2) one team has 21 at the end of the round, and the winners receive $500 for each point difference in the scores.

If the game ends in a tie, another game begins at zero with the cash award increased by $500 per point. The team with the most money at the end of gameplay (set by the players) wins.

21474.name: Attic Antics
21474.description:
Attic Antics is a party game!

The game where you just might see a side of
your friends that you've never seen before.

This is much more than a drinking game!

Innocently enough you'll move around the board
collecting money for performing various acts of idiocy.
The first player to $5000 wins. Sound simple?
...not so fast. As the money moves around, some
players will be able to buy their way out of
potentially embarrassing situations - and some won't!
As the drinks flow and the money goes, so do the inhibitions! Have a camera ready,
this game is sure to fill a scrapbook with some hilarious pictures.

To see it, visit: www.nomanor.com

21475.name: How a Bill Becomes a Law in Pennsylvania
21475.description:
How a Bill Becomes a Law in Pennsylvania, a Game About the Legislative Process

A game booklet printed and distributed by the Pennsylvania House of Representatives. Subtitled, "A game about the legislative process". Players draw cards that give them the opportunity to try to get a bill made into a law. Drawing cards and moving around the board. One player wins when he manages to get the following three cards. 1. Bill Passes House 2. Bill Passes Senate and 3. Governor Signs Bill.

21476.name: Jay Jay Counts Game
21476.description:
From the publisher:

Watch your preschooler soar as they learn numbers 0-12 with self-correcting matching pairs. Award Winner of Canadian Toy Testing Council.

21477.name: Groovy Girls Pet Show Game
21477.description:
From the publisher:

The Pet Show Game brings the Groovy Girls and their pets together for a fun competition.The pets perform some amazing tricks, with the help of the groovy owners, of course. Game contains Game board, spinner, 4 tokens with bases,2 flying disk dice, 25 game cards, 12 award ribbon cards,3 hurdles and 6 power jump cards.

Includes game board, spinner, 4 tokens with bases, 2 flying disk dice, 25 game cards, 12 award ribbons, 3 hurdles, 6 jumps power cards.

Challenges memory, spelling and sequencing skills

21478.name: Groovy Girls Sleepover Game
21478.description:
From the publisher:

The race to put on your PJ's!

Now it is time for you and your Best Friends to go to the Groovy Girls™ Sleepover! Become your favorite Groovy Girl....Spin the spinner and visit the TERRIFIC TENT, VOGUE VANITY, POSH PARTY, LUSCIOUS LOUNGER and BEAUTIFUL BED....and change into a new outfit each time!

21479.name: Knight Moves
21479.description:
From the publisher's website:

Two combatants must outsmart each other in their attempt to maneuver their sphere to the opposite side of the playing field. But to do so, each rival must first lay down a course of wooden blocks from which their sphere can be catapulted. Moving the blocks like Knights in the game of Chess, precise positioning is of the utmost importance in order for the sphere to capture the win.

In this fast-paced game, suggestive of basketball meets Chess, two players try to move their marble to the opposite side of the board, using 5 wooden "blocks" as passing instruments. A player may either pass the ball or move a block like a Knight in a game of Chess. The ball may be passed in any direction, but the block with a ball may not be moved. It is competitive, it is strategic, and it is quick. So get ready to Razzle-Dazzle your opponent.

Online Play


Super Duper Games
Gamerz (turn based)

21480.name: DiceHoldem
21480.description:
Who needs cards? DiceHoldem™ is the Ideal Portable Poker Game! Played just like Texas Holdem!

Players use a combination of guile and luck, bluff and planning, to compete for the pot.

Using unique dice with the letters H, O, L, D, E, and M on them, players compete to make "hands" of the best combination of their 2 player dice and the 5 community dice. The betting rounds are the same as Texas Holdem and each one rolls another community die.

Variants are included for faster play, advanced play, and "Can't Holdem" (a two-player variant that has players bid for a guess at one of five dice that are thrown).

Set includes a zippered carrying pouch.

21482.name: Het Grote Piramidespel
21482.description:
Get me the magical heart scarab of pharaoh Cheops. It lays in the royal tomb chamber of the great pyramid. The god Seth wants it, and you will obey him. Therefore you must go find the magical scarab. Throw the dice and try to be the first to find it.

"Het grote piramidespel" was included with comic N°21 of the series of Papyrus.
You roll the dice and answer to the trivia questions if you answer is right, you have luck, if it's not, you don't.

note: the game was also included with comic N°22 of the series
of papyrus, with new characters and questions. This way it's possible to play the game with 12.

21484.name: Earth Gone Mad
21484.description:
From the web page-

Overview:
The Mayan calendar is one of the oldest and most accurate calendar systems in human history. Using no more than their knowledge of the Earth, Sun, and stars, the Mayans were able to tabulate days, weeks, months, and years from 3113 BC until December 21, 2012 AD. No one knew why the Mayan calendar ended on that date..
